title: cypress --quiet flag not working when component testing

labels.name: scope: testing tools
labels.description: Issues related to Cypress / Jest support in Nx

body:
### Current Behavior

When doing a component test via nx (`yarn nx component-test <project>`) some flags will work e.g. the --spec flag (`yarn nx component-test <project> --spec <some-file>`).
The `--quiet` flag does not work however. You get the summary regardless of the flag:
```
 (Results)

  ┌────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
  │ Tests:        1                                                                                │
  │ Passing:      1                                                                                │
  │ Failing:      0                                                                                │
  │ Pending:      0                                                                                │
  │ Skipped:      0                                                                                │
  │ Screenshots:  0                                                                                │
  │ Video:        false                                                                            │
  │ Duration:     0 seconds                                                                        │
  │ Spec Ran:     xxx.component.cy.ts                                                          │
  └────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

  XXXComponent
    ✓ renders (38ms)


  1 passing (66ms)

✨  Done in 5.74s.
```

### Expected Behavior

The summary should be hidden like when run via cypress directly (`yarn cypress run --project <projectPath> --component --spec <pathToSpec> --quiet`):

```
  SomeComponent
    ✓ renders (38ms)


  1 passing (66ms)

✨  Done in 5.74s.
```


### GitHub Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

1.
See above

### Nx Report

```shell
Node : 16.19.1
   OS   : darwin arm64
   yarn : 1.22.19

   nx                      : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/js                : 15.9.2

   @nrwl/workspace         : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/angular           : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/cli               : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/cypress           : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/devkit            : 15.9.2
   @nrwl/eslint-plugin-nx  : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/tao               : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/webpack           : 15.8.9
   typescript              : 4.9.5
   ---------------------------------------
   Community plugins:
   @ngrx/effects                  : 15.4.0
   @ngrx/entity                   : 15.4.0
   @ngrx/router-store             : 15.4.0
   @ngrx/store                    : 15.4.0
   apollo-angular                 : 4.2.1
   @ngrx/store-devtools           : 15.4.0
   @trifork/nx-angular-generators : 0.0.66

title: Imports from .mts files not detected in nx graph

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
When source files for any library are with .mts extension, the NX graph does not detect its dependencies. This works correctly when using .ts extension.

## Motivation
Ability to use .mts extension for writing source code when using NX

## Suggested Implementation
TypeScriptImportLocator class can be modified to support ".mts" extension. Let me know if this is not the correct approach

## Alternate Implementations
Users will need to rename their existing .mts files to .ts

title: Nx generate fails to run yarn install commands with Yarn 3 and custom registries.
body:
### Current Behavior

When running a generator which is missing plugins, I.E. @nrwl/react:application without having cypress/webpack/web installed, Nx fails at the yarn add steps.

```
Fetching @nrwl/cypress...

 >  NX   Command failed: yarn add -D @nrwl/cypress@15.9.3
```

However, copy/pasting the command that it says failed, works perfectly fine.

### Expected Behavior

Nx should be able to run `yarn add` without problems.

### GitHub Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set project to use yarn 3.5
2. Use a yarnrc.yaml in the project which points to custom registries.
3. Run a generate command which requires additional plugins, such as `yarn nx g @nrwl/react:application` without having @nrwl/cypress installed.


### Nx Report

```shell
nx                      : 15.9.3
   @nrwl/js                : 15.9.3
   @nrwl/linter            : 15.9.3
   @nrwl/workspace         : 15.9.3
   @nrwl/eslint-plugin-nx  : 15.9.3
   @nrwl/react             : 15.9.3
   typescript              : 4.9.5
```


### Failure Logs

```shell
Fetching @nrwl/cypress...

 >  NX   Command failed: yarn add -D @nrwl/cypress@15.9.3

   Pass --verbose to see the stacktrace.
```


### Additional Information

We're pointing at internal registries in our corporate network which live in Artifactory npm mirrors. The registries are required to use the Artifactory API keys from the yarnrc.yaml file to authenticate.

title: Docs: cypress component testing config syntax
body:
### Documentation issue

<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

- [ ] Reporting a typo
- [ ] Reporting a documentation bug
- [x] Documentation improvement
- [ ] Documentation feedback

<!--
  If your issue is not regarding the documentation, please choose an issue type:
  https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/new/choose
-->

### Is there a specific documentation page you are reporting?

https://nx.dev/packages/cypress/documents/cypress-component-testing#cypress-component-testing

### Additional context or description

Would be nice if the syntax for changing cypress.config.ts could be documented. I ran into [this issue](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/13820) as well.

The natural thing to do:
```
export default defineConfig({
  component: nxComponentTestingPreset(__filename),
  video: false,
})
```

The real way to do it:
```
export default defineConfig({
  component: {
    ...nxComponentTestingPreset(__filename),
    video: false,
  }
})
```


Would be nice if this example could be included in the docs

title: Anti-feature request: please do not autoformat files on migration
body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
While migrating Nx from v15 to v16, every file where "@nrwl" was found, every such file was auto-formatted using some your formatting rules. It screwed our documentation files (.MD) and even some Excel files (.XLSX). Please do not do this.

## Motivation
<!-- Why do you believe this behavior would be beneficial? -->
There is a huge chance that repo has it's own formatting rules and overriding them is not cool.

## Suggested Implementation
<!-- How do you imagine this might work? -->
Maybe move auto-formatting into a separate command, like `nx affected:format`. Or just don't auto-format files, that weren't created (not just updated) by Nx.

title: bug(node plugin): generatePackageJson has broken package.json "@trpc": "server@10.21.1" with pnpm
body:
### Current Behavior

I have a strange error where in pnpm the generated package.json for "generatePackageJson": true outputs 

"@trpc": "server@10.21.1"

rather than

"@trpc/server": "10.21.1"

```
{
  "name": "example-app",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "dependencies": {
    "@trpc": "server@10.21.1",
    "express": "^4.18.1",
    "tslib": "^2.3.0"
  },
  "main": "main.js"
}
```

In my main repo where I'm having this issue it's _only_ `@trpc/server` having issues. e.g. `"@prisma/client": "4.13.0",` works fine.

### Expected Behavior

I would expect

```
{
  "name": "example-app",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "dependencies": {
    "@trpc/server": "10.21.1",
    "express": "^4.18.1",
    "tslib": "^2.3.0"
  },
  "main": "main.js"
}
```

### GitHub Repo

https://github.com/AdditionAddict/package-json-trpc-server-issue

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `pnpm exec nx build example-app --configuration=production`


### Nx Report

```shell
>  NX   Report complete - copy this into the issue template

   OS   : win32 x64

_No response_

I get a `An error occured while creating pruned lockfile` for the minimal repo but this happens in my main repo where this doesn't come up.

title: Module parse failed: Unexpected token (24:7)

labels.name: scope: react
labels.description: Issues related to React support for Nx

body:
### Current Behavior

when running nx serve or nx build on any project that relies on a nx lib package I get the same error.

```
Module parse failed: Unexpected token (24:7)
You may need an appropriate loader to handle this file type, currently no loaders are configured to process this file. See https://webpack.js.org/concepts#loaders
``` 

### Expected Behavior

for the build or serve to work

### GitHub Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

I have no idea what of my project is causing this issue so its hard to reproduce.

If created new a nx lib and a new nx next project and pasted my old in it to see if it was any boilerplate code but I still have same issues. The issue came up after updating nx but I cannot seem to revert it anymore.

title: Nx CLI - ENOENT error during workspace creation

body:
### Current Behavior

When attempting to create an Nx workspace using the following commands:

`npx create-nx-workspace@latest --pm=yarn 
`

`npx create-nx-workspace@latest 
`

`npx create-nx-workspace  
`

`sudo npx create-nx-workspace  
`

The process fails with an ENOENT error, stating that it cannot find a specific file or directory. This issue occurs on both Linux (Pop!_OS) and macOS (M1), with different Node.js versions (18.16.0 and LTS version 16.x.x) , _even. with **sudo** user_ 

### Expected Behavior

The Nx workspace should be created successfully without encountering any errors.


### GitHub Repo

This issue can be reproduced with a fresh installation of the Nx CLI.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `npx create-nx-workspace@latest --pm=yarn`
2. Choose what to create                 · integrated
3. What to create in the new workspace   · angular-monorepo  | empty-monorepo
4. Repository name                       · ProjectName
5. Application name                      · client
6 .Would you like to use Standalone Components in your application? · Yes
7.  Would you like to add routing? · No
8. Default stylesheet format             · scss
9. Enable distributed caching to make your CI faster · Yes

title: Error when connecting to Nx Cloud. Code: 404. Error: Request failed with status code 404. Azure DevOps pipeline.
body:
### Current Behavior

Until today everything was working ok, no changes in configuration.

Currently when building project in AzureDevOps pipeline I get 404 response when retrieving artifacts from cache.

Fore some projects in the same pipeline it's working correctly 
NX   Nx Cloud: Downloading 1a6da396202e1c905e15d00eecbd1ddecc78f86d649b1e8983684d1c166bfd2d
NX   Nx Cloud: Downloaded 1a6da396202e1c905e15d00eecbd1ddecc78f86d649b1e8983684d1c166bfd2d

for other 
NX   Nx Cloud: Downloading ba3e757ea89d87550b1c0f25680da80f640d3719de7279ecd4cab497fcc32827
NX   Received 404. Retrying in 5433.70266490442ms.

Tried updating nx-cloud to latest version - no success.


### Expected Behavior

nx can download cached resources.

### GitHub Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

1.
nx run visual-trial-api-client:build:production

title: Add configuration environment via NestJS jest test

labels.name: scope: misc
labels.description: Misc issues

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [x] I'd be willing to help implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
<!-- What is the behavior that you would like to see introduced? -->
npx nx run api:test:mock

the project.json will get the mock configuration and replace the environment file accordingly.
and than i can run the NestJS test with any configuration i want such as the server address or any other setup variable.


## Motivation
<!-- Why do you believe this behavior would be beneficial? -->
this future almost prevent us from implementing tests for the NestJS Api because we cano't test it with mock data or with changing environment like via serve
 
## Suggested Implementation
<!-- How do you imagine this might work? -->
some project.json configuration that will allow npx nx run api:test:<configuration> with NestJS jest.

title: be able to extend schema.json

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
<!-- What is the behavior that you would like to see introduced? -->
Sometimes there's a need to have generator to extend other generators. There're few even in nx repo, when generators are reused for specific purpose, e.g. host/remote generators for react and angular, that call `application` generator under the hood and use the same options as a base one. 

It creates an additional maintenance point when base generator is updated, as it's needed to always apply schema updates to all implementations and keep them in sync without any validations of the process.

## Suggested Implementation
<!-- How do you imagine this might work? -->
I was thinking about the possibility to extend schema.json with a deep merge of properties field and an ability to omit some of them (might be handy if specific properties are set internally by derived generator)

title: [@nrwl/cypress] Unable to run Cypress e2e tests on nest app when using `@nestjs/swagger`

labels.name: scope: testing tools
labels.description: Issues related to Cypress / Jest support in Nx

body:
### Current Behavior

Attempting to run Cypress e2e tests on a __nest__ app when using an annotated dto with an `@ApiProperty()` decorator from `@nestjs/swagger` fails with a webpack error.

`src/dto/cat.dto.ts`:
```typescript
import { ApiProperty } from '@nestjs/swagger';

export class CatDto {
  @ApiProperty()
  name: string;
}
```

`cypress/e2e/dto.cy.ts`:
```typescript
import { CatDto } from '../../src/dto/cat.dto';

describe('@nrwl/cypress', () => {
  it('can instantiate a dto annotated with an ApiProperty decorator', () => {
    new CatDto();
  });
});
```

### Expected Behavior

Since `@nrwl/cypress` are both `@nrwl/nest` parts of the `nx` core packages __Cypress__ should run flawlessly on a standard __nest__ project.

While I agree `@nestjs/swagger` isn't installed by default on a __nest__ project, it's a pretty standard usecase : build and test a *well documented* API with __Cypress__.

### GitHub Repo

https://github.com/larriereguichet/nestjs-cypress-nx

### Steps to Reproduce

```console
git clone git@github.com:larriereguichet/nestjs-cypress-nx.git
cd nestjs-cypress-nx
npm install
npx nx run my-nest-app-cypress:e2e
```

```


### Additional Information

I suppose it's because __nest__ works with __supertest__ by default but this was qualified as a `wont-fix` in __nest__ and locked in the minute : https://github.com/nestjs/nest/issues/11531

> You may find another minimum reproducible example which only uses __nest__ & __cypress__ there : https://github.com/larriereguichet/nestjs-cypress

The issue could probably be fixed by tweaking the webpack/vite configuration in  `@nrwl/cypress` but I fail at finding the how and where this should be done.

body:
### Current Behavior

This morning I saw this issue showing up in our main gitlab pipeline:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2809483/233276814-a53fd553-640a-434d-9263-9c2c8a337c41.png)

The orchestrator reports "all jobs done" before 2/6 agents actually finished their work. We're connected to nx cloud obviously and all jobs are actually posted there correctly. 

Unfortunately, if one of the remaining jobs fail (after the orchestrator stopped and reported "all good"), the orchestrator job in gitlab will still succeed and since the agents always succeed nevertheless they have failed jobs, it looks like everything is fine.

### Expected Behavior

The dte orchestrator should wait until all agents have finished their work.

### GitHub Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

The orchestrator configuration:

```yaml
Nx DTE Orchestrator:
  variables:
    NX_CLOUD_DISTRIBUTED_EXECUTION: "true"
  stage: build
  script:
    - npx nx-cloud start-ci-run
    - npx nx-cloud record -- npx nx workspace-lint --base=$NX_BASE --head=$NX_HEAD
    - npx nx-cloud record -- npx nx format:check --base=$NX_BASE --head=$NX_HEAD
    - npx nx-cloud record -- npm audit --production --audit-level=moderate
    - npx nx-cloud record -- npm audit --audit-level=moderate
    - npx nx run-many --all --target=build --parallel=1 & npx nx run-many --all --target=lint --quiet --parallel=1 & npx nx run-many --all --target=test --ci --code-coverage --forceExit --parallel=1 & npx nx run-many --all --target=playwright  --parallel=1
    - npx nx-cloud stop-all-agents 
```

The agent configuration:
```yaml
Nx Agent:
  parallel: 6
  script:
    - npx nx-cloud start-agent
  stage: build
```

### Nx Report

```shell
Node : 18.12.1
OS   : win32 x64
npm  : 8.19.2

nx                      : 15.8.5
@nrwl/js                : 15.8.5
@nrwl/jest              : 15.8.5
@nrwl/linter            : 15.8.5
@nrwl/workspace         : 15.8.5
@nrwl/angular           : 15.8.5
@nrwl/cli               : 15.8.5
@nrwl/cypress           : 15.8.5
@nrwl/devkit            : 15.8.5
@nrwl/esbuild           : 15.8.5
@nrwl/eslint-plugin-nx  : 15.8.5
@nrwl/express           : 15.8.5
@nrwl/nest              : 15.8.5
@nrwl/node              : 15.8.5
@nrwl/rollup            : 15.8.5
@nrwl/tao               : 15.8.5
@nrwl/web               : 15.8.5
@nrwl/webpack           : 15.8.5
@nrwl/nx-cloud          : 15.3.5
typescript              : 4.9.5
---------------------------------------
Community plugins:
ng2-charts       : 4.1.1
@currents/nx     : 1.0.0-beta.2
@nativescript/nx : 3.0.18
ng-mocks         : 14.7.1
```


### Failure Logs

_No response_

### Additional Information

- I've seen some gitlab pipelines which actually were "successful" but had failing distributed nx jobs. I am still browsing the recent pipelines to see when this issue occurred the first time.
- Using `npx nx-cloud start-ci-run --stop-agents-after=playwright` instead of `npx nx-cloud stop-all-agents` at the end makes things worse: Agents are idling until they get killed by gitlab (after 60 minutes) and the orchestrator still ends before the agents reported their last work

title: Allow setting the "build.target" option in the build options supplied to vite when using the @nrwl/vite executor

labels.name: scope: bundlers
labels.description: Issues related to webpack, rollup

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
Currently I have a monorepo with several packages using [@nrwl/vite:build](https://nx.dev/packages/vite/executors/build) executor, I need to change the [build.target](https://vitejs.dev/config/build-options.html#build-target) option of vitejs to “es2017”. I have tried to change the option in vite.config.ts as the vite [documentation](https://nx.dev/packages/vite/executors/build#options) specifies, but no luck, I also checked the executor documentation and they don’t mention anything about it. Going through the source code of @nrwl/vite:build I found the following function “[getViteBuildOptions](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/00f424acc671db75f1efc6120ff8665bde5cb1b3/packages/vite/src/utils/options-utils.ts#L142)” which specifically sets the target to “esnext”, I modified the package (@nrwl/vite) locally in my node_modules and my bundle was built correctly using es2017. I don’t know if this is a bug or a new feature, but there should be a way to change that vite option using the @nrwl/vite executor. Is there a way that I don’t know yet to change the target from “esnext” to “es2017”?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12108601/232963118-f38906f6-8ef0-4aa7-8d50-71c505da165b.png)


## Motivation
Developers who have specific runtimes cannot customize their build target. The executor does not allow changing the build target provided to vitejs.

I tried this https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/3397 but it didn't work, because the files changed are outside the storybook project.
If I have to build the entire "storybook" project just if some library have been changed its ok for me.


## Suggested Implementation
I tried to configure my nx.json file with an implicit dependency but I don't know if its the correct way to deal with it. 

```json
{

        ....
        "./my-folder/**/*.[ts,scss,html]": ["storybook"]
    },
    ....
}
```

title: Angular 16.0.0-rc.1 : TypeError: validator is not a function + Yarn PnP
body: ### Current Behavior On an Nx 15.9.2 repo, after upgrading Angular to 16.0.0-rc.1 using ```sh nx migrate @angular/cli@next nx migrate @angular/core@next ``` I stumbled upon the following error when running `nx build my-app` ``` TypeError: validator is not a function at /.../node_modules/@angular-devkit/architect/src/jobs/simple-scheduler.js:219:20 at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5) ``` After some investigation, I noticed that this error happens because `@angular-devkit/architect` version here is 16.0.0-rc.0 while `@angular-devkit/core` is 15.2.6. Using `yarn why @angular-devkit/core` I noticed that the hoisted version of the package is `16.0.0-rc.0` which is shadowed by a `15.2.6` version in `node_modules/nx/node_modules/@angular-devkit/core` Cf. yarn why output How is that possible? Is it because Nx depends on RxJS which depends on @angular-devkit/schematics? ### Expected Behavior no error ### GitHub Repo _No response_ ### Steps to Reproduce TODO: I'll add this as soon as I can ### Nx Report ```shell TODO: I'll add this as soon as I can ``` ### Failure Logs _No response_ ### Additional Information _No response_

title: Migration from Nx 13.9.5 to latest does not work ("NX Decoration of the Angular CLI did not complete successfully")
body:
### Current Behavior

Migration from Nx 13.9.5 to latest (15.9.2) does not work using `npx nx migrate latest`.

`npm i` shows this message: "NX Decoration of the Angular CLI did not complete successfully" 

Running the migrations with `npx nx migrate --run-migrations` shows this output:

```
...
 >  NX   Failed to run update-platform-server-exports from @nrwl/angular. This workspace is NOT up to date!


 >  NX   rule is not a function

   Pass --verbose to see the stacktrace.

Command failed: npx nx _migrate --run-migrations

 >  NX   Command failed: npx nx migrate --run-migrations

   Pass --verbose to see the stacktrace.
```


### Expected Behavior

Migration from Nx 13.9.5 to latest should work

### GitHub Repo

https://github.com/spierala/mini-rx-store

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `npm i`
2. `npx nx migrate latest`
3. Adjust package json:     "angular-in-memory-web-api": "^0.15.0",     "ngx-toastr": "^15.2.2"
4. Delete package-lock, node-modules (otherwise npm i fails)
5. `npm i `
6. See the message "NX Decoration of the Angular CLI did not complete successfully"
7. Run migrations: `npx nx migrate latest`
8. See migrations failing: 
```
 >  NX   Failed to run update-platform-server-exports from @nrwl/angular. This workspace is NOT up to date!


 >  NX   rule is not a function

   Pass --verbose to see the stacktrace.

Command failed: npx nx _migrate --run-migrations

This is happening only when nestjs app is inside of nx monorepo.

nestjs app should be able to access cookie-parser types after installing them (npm i -D @types/cookie-parser)

import * as cookieParser from 'cookie-parser';

title: Update tsconfig lib version in tsconfig.base.json.

labels.name: scope: misc
labels.description: Misc issues

body:
- [✅]  I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
Currently, and it seems it's been this way from the beginning, the default `<workspaceRoot>/tsconfig.base.json` defines `"lib": ["es2017", "dom"]` as `compilerOptions`. It would be beneficial to update the ECMAScript version used to a newer one (ES2019+) for developers to take advantage of newer ECMAScript features.

Are there any backwards compatibility requirements that NX is looking at?

## Motivation
Newer versions of ECMAScript define many new APIs, like `Array.prototype.flat`, `String.prototype.trimStart` and others, which would allow for a much more fluid developer experience. An absolute majority of these features are already supported by browsers across the board (even Safari, yes).

## Suggested Implementation
Change `tsconfig.base.json > compilerOptions.lib` to a newer ES version when generating a new workspace.

title: Linting with affected or run-many --all fails when creating libraries and switching branches

labels.name: blocked: retry with latest
labels.description: Retry with latest release or head.

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
### Current Behavior

When creating a new library and then checking out out another branch or commit, and running use `npx nx run-many --target=lint --all`, it fails. It also fails with `npx nx affected` if you've made a change to a file that affects all projects (e.g. package.json). I've seen two different cases of errors — `No ESLint configuration found` in the newly created directory,  or `NX Invalid lint configuration. Nothing to lint. Please check your lint target pattern(s).`

It even fails when adding `--skip-nx-cache`.

### Expected Behavior

The linting should not fail, as the directories do not exist. 

### GitHub Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Make a workspace
2. Make an initial commit
3. Make a @nrwl/js library
4. `npx nx run-many --all --target=lint` — it passes
5. `git commit`
6. `git checkout HEAD^`
7. `npx run-many --all --target=lint` — it fails

Alternatively, starting with the 4th step:

4. `npx nx affected --target=lint` — it passes
5. `git commit`
6. Make another @nrwl/js library
7. `npx nx affected --target=lint` — it passes
8. `git commit` 
6. `git checkout HEAD^`
10. Install some random package - `npm i cowsay`
11. `npx nx affected --target=lint` — it fails.

title: Allow for generated package.json to include dependency range from root package.json
body:
One of my favorite features of Nx is that I don't have to think about managing my package.json for publishable packages because Nx will ensure the generated package.json will have all the dependencies I used and none that I didn't use. This is no longer the case in v15 as it's using the strict versions from my package-lock file, and it's making managing dependencies across my projects very difficult. I understand the position of the team (below), but I'm wondering if we can be provided with the _option_ to use the same version (range) from the root package.json.

> Also, the new generated pacakge json may have adverse impacts for publishable npm packages as the range specified is important and needs to be included in the generated package json. This also impacts any publishable package using the @nrwl/js:tsc executor.

For publishable packages we suggest creating manual package.json instead of using generated one, **because** it gives you the freedom to specify ranges as you see fit. For example my library could support `@angular/core: >= 10 < 15` but my root package.json would have probably something like `@angular/core: ^14.2.0`. Using root package json ranges for publishable libs is bad practice, as they tend to be more restrictive than needed.

_Originally posted by @meeroslav in https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/12675#issuecomment-1301366002_

title: running @nrwl/vite:test with single file or list of files

labels.name: scope: bundlers
labels.description: Issues related to webpack, rollup

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [x] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
<!-- What is the behavior that you would like to see introduced? -->
Ability to run `@nrwl/vite:test` with a `--testFile` or `--testFiles` argument. Like what is available in `@nrwl/jest:jest` (jest has [--testFile](packages/vite/src/executors/test/vitest.impl.ts))
## Motivation
<!-- Why do you believe this behavior would be beneficial? -->
It would make the developer experience better when writing and debugging single test files.
## Suggested Implementation
<!-- How do you imagine this might work? -->
modify `vitestExecutor` in `packages/vite/src/executors/test/vitest.impl.ts` to pass value from `--testFiles` argument to `startVitest`
```diff
+ const testFiles = options.testFiles?.split(' ');
+ const ctx = await startVitest(options.mode, testFiles ?? [], settings);
- const ctx = await startVitest(options.mode, [], settings);
``` 
## Alternate Implementations
<!-- How else do you imagine this might work? -->
For single file (`--testFile`):
```diff
+ const cliFilters = options.testFiles ? [options.testFile] : [];
+ const ctx = await startVitest(options.mode, cliFilters, settings);
- const ctx = await startVitest(options.mode, [], settings);
```

### Current Behavior

Errors during CI execution caused by different environments

While running on CI Github Actions I'm having issues with `NX I can't find module '@nrwl/nx-linux-x64-gnu'`

### Expected Behavior

Running the integration tasks proceeds exactly as they are running locally, as all versions are equalized:

### CI (Github Action)

   npm: 9.5.0
   yarn: 1.22.19
```

### Local
```shell
    Node: 18.15.0
    OS: darwinarm64
    npm: 9.5.0
```


I tried to add it as a devDependency but I can't, because I use macOS and I get an error from npm

```shell

### GitHub Repo

https://github.com/guiseek/nx-plugin

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Configure execution with
```yml
name: Pull Request

on: pull_request

env:
   CI: true

jobs:
   check:
     name: checklist
     if: "!contains(github.event.head_commit.message, 'skip ci')"
     runs-on: ubuntu-latest

       - uses: actions/checkout@v3
         with:

           NPM_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.NPM_TOKEN }}

         run: npm ci

       - name: Affected Tests

body:
### Documentation issue

<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

- [ ] Reporting a typo
- [ ] Reporting a documentation bug
- [x] Documentation improvement
- [ ] Documentation feedback

<!--
  If your issue is not regarding the documentation, please choose an issue type:
  https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/new/choose
-->

### Is there a specific documentation page you are reporting?

https://nx.dev/packages/nx/documents/init#usage

### Additional context or description

The documentation page for nx init is lacking the options. I knew from the guide [Migrating from CRA to NX](https://nx.dev/recipes/adopting-nx/migration-cra) that there exist options such as "--integrated" or "--vite=false", but none of them are mentioned in the documentation itself for nx init.

In my case, I needed the "--nxCloud=false" option, as I have reasons for not adding cloud caching to my migration. Since it's not in the documentation, I had to dig around in the [source code](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/packages/nx/src/nx-init/react/index.ts) to find the remaining options, and then test it out.

This is **very cumbersome** for those of us who is migrating from CRA (or any other standalone app), when we need to do adjustments to the migration.

I hereby request that the documentation page is filled with the options available.

<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
<!-- What is the behavior that you would like to see introduced? -->
For example, i added a new eslint rules with override pattern due to this issue https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/5866

I tried to run eslint --fix to apply auto fix

When i run `yarn nx affected --target=lint --fix`, it show
```
 >  NX   Affected criteria defaulted to --base=main --head=HEAD

 >  NX   Successfully ran target lint for 0 projects (8ms)
 
         With additional flags:
           --fix=true
```

And there is no command to run single `target ` with extra arguments for lint fix


I tried `yarn nx run-many --all --target=lint --fix`, but this command cannot pass arguments `--fix`

i tried `yarn nx run lint --fix`, but this command only run for default project

## Motivation
<!-- Why do you believe this behavior would be beneficial? -->
missing function in nx command

## Suggested Implementation
<!-- How do you imagine this might work? -->
add --all arguments to `nx run` simular to `nx run-many`

## Alternate Implementations
<!-- How else do you imagine this might work? -->
Run lint fix on every libs / apps, but this is not pratical with human mistake

body:
### Current Behavior I have two libs: "layout" and "families: - and configured storybook for them using the nextjs version of the storybook generator: https://nx.dev/packages/storybook/documents/storybook-7-setup It works fine at the beginning, but as soon as I try to create a new story in the "families" project, that relies on one component that comes from "layout" lib then storybook doesn't work anymore and throw the following error: ``` ERROR in ./libs/families/src/lib/components/sidebarMenuFamilies/newComponent/newComponent.tsx 3:0-76 Module not found: Error: Can't resolve '@my-project-mono/layout' in '/Users/victor/Documents/dev/my-project-mono/libs/families/src/lib/components/sidebarMenuFamilies/newComponent' resolve '@my-project-mono/layout' in '/Users/victor/Documents/dev/my-project-mono/libs/families/src/lib/components/sidebarMenuFamilies/newComponent' Parsed request is a module using description file: /Users/victor/Documents/dev/my-project-mono/package.json (relative path: ./libs/families/src/lib/components/sidebarMenuFamilies/newComponent) Field 'browser' doesn't contain a valid alias configuration resolve as module /Users/victor/Documents/dev/my-project-mono/libs/families/src/lib/components/sidebarMenuFamilies/newComponent/node_modules doesn't exist or is not a directory ``` Running the project outside storybook everything works fine. ### Expected Behavior Storybook should work fine when there's some component that imports some component from another library in the same monorepo. ### GitHub Repo _No response_ ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Create two nextjs libraries: `nx g @nrwl/next:lib layout ` `nx g @nrwl/next:lib families ` 2-Then configure storybook for both: `nx g @nrwl/storybook:configuration layout --storybook7Configuration --storybook7UiFramework=@storybook/nextjs ` `nx g @nrwl/storybook:configuration families --storybook7Configuration --storybook7UiFramework=@storybook/nextjs ` Now create some component in the layout lib, and import it on families project. The component can be as basic as this: on layout: ``` export function NewComponentLayout() { return
MyComponent
} ``` on families: ``` import {NewComponentLayout} from '@my-project-mono/layout' export function MyComponent() { return } ``` Then run storybook in the families lib and this error will happen: ``` ERROR in ./libs/families/src/lib/components/newComponent/newComponent.tsx 3:0-76 Module not found: Error: Can't resolve '@my-project-mono/layout' in '/Users/victor/Documents/dev/my-project-mono/libs/families/src/lib/components/newComponent' resolve '@my-project-mono/layout' in '/Users/victor/Documents/dev/my-project-mono/libs/families/src/lib/components/newComponent' Parsed request is a module using description file: /Users/victor/Documents/dev/my-project-mono/package.json (relative path: ./libs/families/src/lib/components/newComponent) Field 'browser' doesn't contain a valid alias configuration resolve as module /Users/victor/Documents/dev/my-project-mono/libs/families/src/lib/components/newComponent/node_modules doesn't exist or is not a directory ``` ### Nx Report ```shell Node : 18.7.0 OS : darwin arm64 npm : 8.15.0 nx : 15.9.0-rc.2 @nrwl/js : 15.9.2 @nrwl/jest : 15.9.2 @nrwl/linter : 15.9.2 @nrwl/workspace : 15.9.2 @nrwl/cli : 15.9.2 @nrwl/cypress : 15.9.2 @nrwl/devkit : 15.9.2 @nrwl/eslint-plugin-nx : 15.9.2 @nrwl/next : 15.9.2 @nrwl/react : 15.9.2 @nrwl/storybook : 15.9.2 @nrwl/tao : 15.9.0-rc.2 @nrwl/web : 15.9.2 @nrwl/webpack : 15.9.2 typescript : 4.9.5 --------------------------------------- The following packages should match the installed version of nx - @nrwl/js@15.9.2 - @nrwl/jest@15.9.2 - @nrwl/linter@15.9.2 - @nrwl/workspace@15.9.2 - @nrwl/cli@15.9.2 - @nrwl/cypress@15.9.2 - @nrwl/devkit@15.9.2 - @nrwl/eslint-plugin-nx@15.9.2 - @nrwl/next@15.9.2 - @nrwl/react@15.9.2 - @nrwl/storybook@15.9.2 - @nrwl/web@15.9.2 - @nrwl/webpack@15.9.2 To fix this, run `nx migrate nx@15.9.2` ``` ### Failure Logs _No response_ ### Additional Information _No response_

@nrwl/react-native - select default storage and env package

labels.name: scope: react-native
labels.description: Issues relating to React Native

body:
- [ X] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description

Currently, when you create a new react-native app or add a library, nx installs @react-native-async-storage/async-storage
and react-native-config.

However, I prefer using react-native-mmkv and react-native-ultimate-config. Thus, I'd like the option not to use those two default packages/

## Motivation
Developers would like the opportunity to select what storage and config packages they use.

## Suggested Implementation
When you run `nx g @nrwl/react-native:init ...,` an option is presented to use either the default @react-native-async-storage/async-storage or react-native-config packages or not. If not for either nx sets up the react-native app without installing or setting up the two packages.

## Alternate Implementations
remove those two default packages, and let developers select what they want to use.

Updating 

```js
function createNxCloudWorkspace(workspaceName, installationSource) {
    return __awaiter(this, void 0, void 0, function* () {
        const apiUrl = removeTrailingSlash(process.env.NX_CLOUD_API || process.env.NRWL_API || `https://cloud.nx.app`);
        const response = yield require('axios').post(`${apiUrl}/nx-cloud/create-org-and-workspace`, {
            workspaceName,
            installationSource,
        });
        if (response.data.message) {
            throw new Error(response.data.message);
        }
        return response.data;
    });
}
```

to 
```js
const httpsProxyAgent = require('https-proxy-agent');
const httpsAgent = new httpsProxyAgent(`http://www-proxy.{$company}.ch:8080`);

function createNxCloudWorkspace(workspaceName, installationSource) {
    return __awaiter(this, void 0, void 0, function* () {
        const apiUrl = removeTrailingSlash(process.env.NX_CLOUD_API || process.env.NRWL_API || `https://cloud.nx.app`);
        const response = yield require('axios').post(`${apiUrl}/nx-cloud/create-org-and-workspace`, {
            workspaceName,
            installationSource,
        },{
            httpsAgent: httpsAgent,
            proxy: false,
          });
        if (response.data.message) {
            throw new Error(response.data.message);
        }
        return response.data;
    });
}
```

That "solves" the problem. The problem then pops up at every subsequent axios call to the cloud though.

│       └── axios@0.21.4
└─┬ nx@15.8.5
  └── axios@1.3.4
```` 

Note the difference in terms of versions between `nx-cloud` and `nx`

title: Error: Cannot find module
Support Angular's standalone migration schematic

labels.name: scope: angular
labels.description: Issues related to Angular support in Nx

body:
Seems Angular's standalone migration schematic does not work in a nx monorepo that does not have the angular.json file. I have recently updated my nx workspace (is now v15.9.2) in order to be able to use the standalone migration schematic to gradually migrate a large Angular project to use standalone components as it requires at least Angular v15.2.0. (https://angular.io/guide/standalone-migration)

When running `ng generate @angular/core:standalone` I get the following error:

`Error: This command is not available when running the Angular CLI outside a workspace.`

From what I understand, the reason is that the angular.json does not exist anymore and angular/cli does not detect that I am running the schematic inside an Angular project.

Is Nx going to support Angular's standalone migration schematic? 

Is there any workaround to the missing angular.json or to the error above?

This is something critical for our team, as our project is very large and the standalone schematic seems a very helpful option.

title: ensurePackage doesn't work in pnpm workspaces
body:
### Current Behavior

https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/c53d9c325c2f6309b5f1da493e32e002455e9007/packages/devkit/src/utils/package-json.ts#L451-L454 
`ensurePackage` runs `getPackageManagerCommand().addDev` command in a temp cwd. If the target workspace is pnpm workspace, the command will be `pnpm add -Dw`. In a temp workspace this throws an error, because the temp workspace is not a pnpm workspace. 

### Expected Behavior

It should not use `-Dw` flag for the installation. 

### GitHub Repo

https://github.com/qwikifiers/qwik-ui

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Checkout the repo, run `pnpm install`
2. Run `pnpm exec nx g qwik-nx:app myapp --e2eTestRunner=playwright --style=css --verbose`. Playwright is not added as a dependency, so `qwik-nx` will attempt to install it
3. Notice the error

title: Docs requested for withNx demoing config factory function setup

labels.name: scope: nextjs
labels.description: Issues related to NextJS support for Nx

body:
### Documentation issue

<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

- [ ] Reporting a typo
- [ ] Reporting a documentation bug
- [x] Documentation improvement
- [x] Documentation feedback

<!--
  If your issue is not regarding the documentation, please choose an issue type:
  https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/new/choose
-->

My team and I are upgrading Nx and Next.js app from 13.8 and 12.10 to 15.9.2 and 13.1.1, respectively. One of the things that we ran into without any clear reason was an internal Next.js error along the lines of "the config must be an object, not a function".

This turned out to be because the implicit signature of the `withNx` config plugin from `@nrwl/next` changed in the last month, in this PR from @ndcunningham https://github.com/nrwl/nx/pull/15650. Digging into the source and history of this file I was able to find the PR and [this issue comment](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/15794#issuecomment-1485782908) where @jaysoo has a suggested fix (thank you!)

The fix took us a few hours to figure out. It would be really helpful if the docs and/or reference repo for @nrwl/next illustrated how to use `withNx` when your application needs to use the config factory function. An e2e test that covered this functionality would be excellent, too, but docs would probably be more helpful for devs looking for this issue. I think this is a pretty common project set up; I think the "No changes are required for existing workspaces" statement in the description of the PR that changed the behavior was a big miscalculation.

title: Allow generateFile to return a promise after invoking `tree.write`
body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
I encountered an issue when working with `nx workspace-generator`. In my generator, I am invoking `generateFiles` from `@nrwl/devkit` to create files: that worked without any issue.

However, the next step in my generator involves performing some operations on the generated files (in my use-case, they're generated in new folders that did not exist before). Attempting to access this newly created path will result in an error, because by the time `generateFiles` is finished running, the folders are not guaranteed to have been created in the file system.

Based on my (very limited) understanding of the inner workings of `generateFiles`, it calls `tree.write` internally, which [internally calls `tree.overwrite` or `tree.create`](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/6ba60a0d2f9c46cf7167aa9f3b11f538dceeec49/packages/devkit/src/utils/invoke-nx-generator.ts#L204-L208). The [`write` method contains async logic](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/6ba60a0d2f9c46cf7167aa9f3b11f538dceeec49/packages/devkit/src/utils/invoke-nx-generator.ts#L34-L40) but we are [not returning the promise from `tree.write`](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/6ba60a0d2f9c46cf7167aa9f3b11f538dceeec49/packages/devkit/src/generators/generate-files.ts#L99).

## Motivation
In some complex workspace generation workflow, there might be additional steps after the invocation of `generateFiles` that depends on the files/folders created by this function. However, since this function has some internal async logic, it is not possible to guarantee that the file paths are accessible in the filesystem after `generateFiles` is called.

I hope my request/suggestion makes sense: please let me know if I should add more information or furnish you with additional details ❤️ 

## Suggested Implementation
I do not have a great suggestion for a forward migration path, as returning a promise from `generateFiles()` might break existing workflows of others :( perhaps an Nx maintainer/contributer can help shed some light on a possible implementation suggestion?

## Alternate Implementations
_n.a._

title: Storybook v7 + @storybook/react-vite "importers[path] is not a function" when importing stories from other libs
Support for strictly typed .eslintrc.js
body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

## Description
In a recent project, I moved from `.eslintrc.json` to `.eslintrc.js` for my ESLint configuration. 

I was able to achieve a strictly typed base configuration of the file using the following:
```js
module.exports = /** @type {import('@typescript-eslint/experimental-utils').TSESLint.Linter.Config} */ ({
  ignorePatterns: ['**/*'],
  overrides: [
    // ...
  ],
  plugins: ['jsdoc', 'eslint-plugin-tsdoc', '@nrwl/nx'],
  root: true,
  settings: {
    // ...
  },
});
```
Ref: https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/pull/1296#issuecomment-777709090

With some refactoring of https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/packages/eslint-plugin-nx/src/rules/enforce-module-boundaries.ts could we support strict types as well?

## Motivation
All the benefits of strictly typed TS/JS

## Suggested Implementation
```js
module.exports = /** @type {import('@typescript-eslint/experimental-utils').TSESLint.Linter.Config} */ ({
  ignorePatterns: ['**/*'],
  overrides: [
    {
      extends: ['plugin:jsdoc/recommended', 'plugin:import/recommended'],
      files: ['*.ts', '*.tsx', '*.js', '*.jsx'],
      rules: {
        '@nrwl/nx/enforce-module-boundaries': [
          'error',
          /** @type {import('@nrwl/eslint-plugin-nx').TSESLint.Linter.Config} */ ({
            depConstraints: [
              
            ],
            enforceBuildableLibDependency: false,
          }),
        ],
        
      },
    },
    
  ],
});

```

title: Support for local executors, generators and plugins with `.ts` extension

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
## Description

Support for local executors, generators and plugins written in TypeScript (without manual transpilation).

## Motivation

More and more tools allow `.ts` configuration files. For example:
- Webpack supports `webpack.config.ts`
- Taiwlind CSS added support for `tailwind.config.ts` in recent v3.3
- Storybook is fully configurable via `main.ts` / `manager.ts` / `preview.ts` files since v7.0

It would be nice if NX would support custom workspace executors, generators and plugins written in `.ts` out of the box too.

Currently, it's achievable with solution like this:
```ts
// ./nx.json
{ plugins: ['./nx-plugins/plugin.dist.js'] }

// ./nx-plugins/plugin.dist.js
require("ts-node").register();
module.exports = require("./plugin.ts");

// ./nx-plugins/plugin.ts
import path from "path";
```

But a native support could be more performant (better caching) and more accessible developers.

## Suggested Implementation

NX could transiple custom plugins "on the fly" with one of these packages:
https://www.npmjs.com/package/ts-node
https://www.npmjs.com/package/jiti
https://www.npmjs.com/package/@swc/register

More are mentioned here:
https://github.com/privatenumber/ts-runtime-comparison

Developer would be able to write executor/generator/plugin using common.js/ESM/TypeScript, and NX based on the file extension would decide how it will load it.

title: generateLockfile still fails with pnpm on some specific packages with nx 15.8.9

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
### Current Behavior

When enabling generateLockfile in a nx workspace using pnpm for a node application, the build of the lockfile for the application fails when some package are used in a lib referenced in the application.

May be related to issue #15123 which was quite similar.

### Expected Behavior

The pnpm-lock.yaml file should be generated in dist folder without error.

### GitHub Repo

https://github.com/BatmanTheBlind/nx-issue-lockfile-and-pnpm

### Steps to Reproduce

Here is a repository to reproduce the issue : https://github.com/BatmanTheBlind/nx-issue-lockfile-and-pnpm

If you don't have pnpm installed, you can install it with `npm install -g pnpm`.

Then just execute the following commands:

1. `git clone https://github.com/BatmanTheBlind/nx-issue-lockfile-and-pnpm`
2. `pnpm i`
3. `nx build my-app`

title: Issues working with the Expo plugin

labels.name: scope: react-native
labels.description: Issues relating to React Native

body:
### Current Behavior

I'm looking at using Expo to build an app and I'm working on a proof of concept setup using Nx. 

I tried to get it working following the instructions in the [docs](https://nx.dev/packages/expo), but I'm running into various issues. Some of which might be related. 



### Expected Behavior

Following the instructions in the docs should lead to a working setup that we can build, run and deploy to [Expo Application Services (EAS)](https://expo.dev/eas).

### GitHub Repo

https://github.com/beeman/testexpo

### Steps to Reproduce

1. `npx create-nx-workspace --preset=expo`
  - Repository name: `testexpo`
  - Application name: `expo`
  - Nx Cloud: `Yes`
2. `cd testexpo`
3. `nx start expo`
4. Hit `i` to open the iOS simulator, then when the app loads, this error appears:

```
Require cycles are allowed, but can result in uninitialized values. Consider refactoring to remove the need for a cycle.
 ERROR  TypeError: (0, _expo.registerRootComponent) is not a function. (In '(0, _expo.registerRootComponent)(_App.default)', '(0, _expo.registerRootComponent)' is undefined)
 ERROR  Invariant Violation: Failed to call into JavaScript module method AppRegistry.runApplication(). Module has not been registered as callable. Registered callable JavaScript modules (n = 11): Systrace, JSTimers, HeapCapture, SamplingProfiler, RCTLog, RCTDeviceEventEmitter, RCTNativeAppEventEmitter, GlobalPerformanceLogger, JSDevSupportModule, HMRClient, RCTEventEmitter.
        A frequent cause of the error is that the application entry file path is incorrect. This can also happen when the JS bundle is corrupt or there is an early initialization error when loading React Native.
 ERROR  Invariant Violation: Failed to call into JavaScript module method AppRegistry.runApplication(). Module has not been registered as callable. Registered callable JavaScript modules (n = 11): Systrace, JSTimers, HeapCapture, SamplingProfiler, RCTLog, RCTDeviceEventEmitter, RCTNativeAppEventEmitter, GlobalPerformanceLogger, JSDevSupportModule, HMRClient, RCTEventEmitter.
        A frequent cause of the error is that the application entry file path is incorrect. This can also happen when the JS bundle is corrupt or there is an early initialization error when loading React Native.
```

5. Another error is when I want to run the iOS as suggested in the docs (`nx run-ios expo`) which leads to the following error:

```
› Installing using npm
Error: npm exited with non-zero code: 1
Error: npm exited with non-zero code: 1
    at ChildProcess.completionListener (/private/tmp/testexpo/node_modules/@expo/spawn-async/build/spawnAsync.js:52:23)
    at Object.onceWrapper (node:events:628:26)
    at ChildProcess.emit (node:events:513:28)
    at maybeClose (node:internal/child_process:1091:16)
    at Socket.<anonymous> (node:internal/child_process:449:11)
    at Socket.emit (node:events:513:28)
    at Pipe.<anonymous> (node:net:313:12)
    ...
    at spawnAsync (/private/tmp/testexpo/node_modules/@expo/spawn-async/build/spawnAsync.js:17:21)
    at NpmPackageManager._runAsync (/private/tmp/testexpo/node_modules/@expo/package-manager/build/NodePackageManagers.js:133:51)
    at NpmPackageManager.installAsync (/private/tmp/testexpo/node_modules/@expo/package-manager/build/NodePackageManagers.js:59:20)
    at NpmPackageManager.addWithParametersAsync (/private/tmp/testexpo/node_modules/@expo/package-manager/build/NodePackageManagers.js:68:25)
    at installPackagesAsync (/private/tmp/testexpo/node_modules/@expo/cli/build/src/install/installAsync.js:82:26)
    at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5)
    at async Object.prebuildAsync (/private/tmp/testexpo/node_modules/@expo/cli/build/src/prebuild/prebuildAsync.js:75:9)
    at async Object.ensureNativeProjectAsync (/private/tmp/testexpo/node_modules/@expo/cli/build/src/run/ensureNativeProject.js:24:9)
    at async runIosAsync (/private/tmp/testexpo/node_modules/@expo/cli/build/src/run/ios/runIosAsync.js:47:9)
``` 

6. It looks like this error is fixed by doing `cd apps/expo && npm install --legacy-peer-deps && cd ..` but after that, I get the following error:

```
❯ nx run-ios expo

> nx run expo:run-ios

info Dependencies for 'expo' are up to date! No changes made.
⚠️  Something went wrong running `pod install` in the `ios` directory.
Command `pod install` failed.
└─ Cause: Unable to find a specification for `ExpoModulesCore` depended upon by `Expo`

You have either:
 * mistyped the name or version.
 * not added the source repo that hosts the Podspec to your Podfile.
 ```


You can find a [repro here](https://github.com/beeman/testexpo). I also tried it using a manual setup (as per the docs), using `yarn` over `npm`, but it all seems to come back to the errors above.



### Nx Report

```shell

Happy to help test or troubleshoot things, or jump on a Zoom to show what I'm running into.

Expo with EAS seems like a very compelling setup, but, as you folks know, I wouldn't want to use it without Nx ;)

body:
### Documentation issue

<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

- [ ] Reporting a typo
- [X] Reporting a documentation bug
- [ ] Documentation improvement
- [ ] Documentation feedback

<!--
  If your issue is not regarding the documentation, please choose an issue type:
  https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/new/choose
-->

### Is there a specific documentation page you are reporting?

[@nrwl/next -> Setting up Next.js](https://nx.dev/packages/next#setting-up-next.js)

### Additional context or description

With changes from https://github.com/nrwl/nx/pull/15824 package `@nrwl/next` needs to be included in `dependencies`, not in the `devDependencies`, otherwise generated `package.json` doesn't have `@nrwl/next` and it's not possible to run the Next's application because of error:

```
error - Failed to load next.config.js, see more info here https://nextjs.org/docs/messages/next-config-error
Error: Cannot find module '@nrwl/next/plugins/with-nx'
```

Workspace generated by command `npx create-nx-workspace@latest --preset=next` have `@nrwl/next` in the `dependencies`.

body:
### Current Behavior

Hi,

We are using NX on our TeamCity build server. It seems that the latest version, 15.8.9, is not working for us and throws the following error when running the Cypress end-to-end testing (or another NX command, e.g. nx report) on our Angular project. Note we add NX as a global package:

_Error: Cannot find module 'nx/package.json'_

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67626158/228110319-2e15db5f-7f89-489e-a3b6-b905beeeca28.png)


Doing precisely the same, but downgrading NX to version 15.8.7 works.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67626158/228113422-b55d756e-6cb4-415c-85d9-2b8a27cc8ff4.png)

Also, we can't retrieve the broken version report since it does not allow us to run NX commands. I've attached a report for 15.8.7 (which is working). 

Thanks for your help.

Regards,

Expect NX 15.8.8-9 to work the same as 15.8.7

_No response_

1. Install NX globally 15.8.9 `yarn global add nx@15.8.9`

title: bug(nx-plugin):  e2e tests fail for new plugin workspace
body:
### Current Behavior

Creating a new plugin workspace and running e2e test fails.
There's also a jest coverageDirectory validation warning.

### Expected Behavior

e2e run and pass without warnings / warning if I'm putting wrong settings for create-nx-plugin

### GitHub Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

1.  `npx create-nx-plugin extruda-nx --pluginName=workspace --packageManager=pnpm`
2.  `cd extruda-nx`
3.  (added Nx Cloud DTE)
4.  `pnpm exec nx run workspace-e2e:e2e --verbose`

title: Cypress e2e tests go into endless loop in `--watch` mode with Vite

labels.name: scope: testing tools
labels.description: Issues related to Cypress / Jest support in Nx

body:
### Current Behavior

When you run Cypress in watch mode like this `nx run cart-e2e:e2e --watch` it goes into an endless loop and never running or displaying the tests. Running the tests in `nx run cart-e2e:e2e --headed` mode does not have this issue. 

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36489034/227706848-d55d8f00-1f91-4205-8acd-ac19946d1b93.mov



### Expected Behavior

Running `nx run cart-e2e:e2e --watch` should run the tests as normal, and re-run on file changes only. 

### GitHub Repo

https://github.com/vemundeldegard/nx-vite-example

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Clone nx-examples repo `gh repo clone nrwl/nx-examples`
2. Run `yarn` to install packages
3. Run `nx run cart-e2e:e2e --watch` and select chrome as the browser
4. Click on the `app.cy.ts` test file to run this test

### Nx Report

```shell
Node : 16.13.1
   OS   : darwin arm64
   yarn : 1.22.17
   
   nx                      : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/js                : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/linter            : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/workspace         : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/cli               : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/cypress           : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/devkit            : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/eslint-plugin-nx  : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/react             : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/tao               : 15.8.9
   @nrwl/vite              : 15.8.9
   typescript              : 4.9.5
```

title: Rename generator

labels.name: scope: misc
labels.description: Misc issues

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion-type issue instead. -->

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
- rename project generator. 
- similar to nx move / nx remove the generator. 
- helps us to rename an app/lib 

## Motivation
- Normally when we start a project we create one serverless lambda app with @ns3/nx-serverless
- But as the application progress we might need to move them to sub-folders and make the group of serverless functions based on domain/deployment patterns
- The way we do it now is to move the application and manually update the names in each place it is referenced
- If we have a generator that does in one go the process got simplified

## Suggested Implementation
- similar to the move generator it accepts the project name & new project name
- when we run the generator it will update the typescript references & nx configs with a new name

## Alternate Implementations
<!-- How else do you imagine this might work? -->

body:
## Description
Export utils from `@nrwl/angular/src/utils/nx-devkit` with an public API

## Motivation
When writing custom generators, some nx-devkit internal utilities would come in very handy instead of writing an own implementation

## Suggested Implementation
I would like to be able to e.g. `import {addImportToDirective} from '@nrwl/angular/generators'` in order be be able to use it in my customer generator

## Alternate Implementations
The only alternative currently is to copy the code to our own codebase, which tbh isn't actually a good alternative

title: A utility to get Module Federation config

labels.name: scope: react
labels.description: Issues related to React support for Nx

labels.name: scope: angular
labels.description: Issues related to Angular support in Nx

body:
- [x] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
I am currently [working](https://github.com/module-federation/universe/pull/598) on implementing a Storybook addon that supports Module Federation. In order to complete the pull request, I need to create two React Module Federation apps using Nx.

To achieve this, I have started to create two apps using the command `nx g @nrwl/react:host react-storybook --remotes=react-remote-ui` and have added Storybook to `react-storybook`. However, I am encountering a problem with extracting the Module Federation config from `withModuleFederation` and changing the `library` config.

I would appreciate any suggestions or solutions for resolving these issues, as they are critical for completing my PR.

Thank you for your help!

title: Tree doesn't handle moves properly
body:
### Current Behavior

When using the move generator to move a generated directory, files that exist in a sub-directory that was deleted before a file is created in the sub-directory don't get moved. They disappear into the ether.

### Expected Behavior

When moving a generated directory, all of the files in the directory should be moved.

### GitHub Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

Obviously a very contrived example but still:

1. tree.delete('folder/abc')
2. tree.write('folder/abc/def.txt', 'my text')
3. tree.children('folder')
4. // should be 'abc' but it's an empty array - meanwhile tree.exists('folder/abc/def.txt') is true



### Nx Report

```shell
nx 14.4.3 (but seems to have the same issue on master)
```


### Failure Logs

_No response_

### Additional Information

So the issue is in tree.ts and there's a bunch of them.

If you delete a path, it sets the path to "isDeleted" in the recorded changes. To solve this, you would think that you could just set isDeleted to false in the write function when a new file is written to a folder previously deleted. 

That backfires a bit because isDeleted is used to determine if something is a file. So now the tree thinks that this folder is actually a file which means that the "visitNotIgnoredFiles" function that recursively checks folders thinks this path is a file.

To fix that, in the delete function, you can set isDeleted to true ONLY in the case that filePath is a folder. This also makes more sense in the output for a generator because right now, it shows folders and files as deleted (which is weird, just show me that the folder is deleted OR the files that were deleted, not both).

title: Add simpleName option to @nrwl/js:lib generator
body:
## Description
The @nrwl/angular:library generator has a [simpleName](https://nx.dev/packages/angular/generators/library#simplename) option that omits the directory from the generated files. It would be very nice to include this option in the @nrwl/js:lib generator as well. Using grouping folders as recommended [here](https://nx.dev/more-concepts/grouping-libraries) results in unwieldy file names otherwise.

## Motivation
Using grouping folders to organize libs becomes impractical without this option.

## Suggested Implementation
Analogous to [simpleName](https://nx.dev/packages/angular/generators/library#simplename)

## Alternate Implementations
-

body:
### Current Behavior Hello Nx Team, #### Context I'm trying to use nx to build a monorepository in a Podman container for local development. #### Technical details - package manager: pnpm@7.9.4 - nx v15.0.13 - This container uses a dedicated volume for the node_modules for performances reasons - The code files are mounted as volume from the filesystem - Image based on node:16-alpine3.16 with root user - Image built for mac M1 amd64 architecture #### Observed behavior
1. Nx hangs at the post-install step: `.../.pnpm/nx@15.0.13/node_modules/nx postinstall: > NX Daemon Server - Stopped` I have to use Ctrl+C to stop it and the following error message is then displayed: `Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'slice')` 2. I can then check that nx daemon is indeed not running, even when trying to run `nx reset` or `nx setup` before 3. If I try to build my project using nx, I have the following output: `nx build my-project` `NX Nx Daemon was not able to compute the project graph.` ` ` `Log file with the error: /__path__/my-project/node_modules/.cache/nx/d/daemon-error.log` `Please file an issue at https://github.com/nrwl/nx` `Nx Daemon is going to be disabled until you run "nx reset".` ` ` ` ⠹ Nx is waiting on 41 dependent project tasks before running tasks from my-project...` ` ` `———————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————` ` ` `NX Ran target build for project my-project and 41 task(s) it depends on (1s)` ` ` ` ✖ 0/0 failed` ` ✔ 0/0 succeeded [0 read from cache]` ` ` `NX Cannot read properties of null (reading 'write')` ` ` `Pass --verbose to see the stacktrace.` Additionally, no output is displayed for several minutes after the line `Nx Daemon is going to be disabled until you run "nx reset".`. ### Expected Behavior I expect: 1. Nx not to hang at post-install step even when Nx daemon deactivates itself. 2. Nx to be able to build my project in a local Podman container even with its daemon deactivated. ### GitHub Repo _No response_ ### Steps to Reproduce Try to build and run a monorepository in a Podman container with nx under the following conditions : 1. package manager: pnpm@7.9.4 2. nx v15.0.13 3. This container uses a dedicated volume for the node_modules for performances reasons 4. The code files are mounted as volume from the filesystem 5. Image based on node:16-alpine3.16 with root user 6. Image built for amd64 and running on Mac M1 Then, you should observe: 1. The install will hang on nx post-install step 2. the build will hang and then finally fail ### Nx Report ```shell > NX Report complete - copy this into the issue template Node : 16.19.1 OS : linux x64 pnpm : 7.9.4 nx : 15.0.13 @nrwl/angular : Not Found @nrwl/cypress : Not Found @nrwl/detox : Not Found @nrwl/devkit : 15.3.0 @nrwl/esbuild : Not Found @nrwl/eslint-plugin-nx : Not Found @nrwl/expo : Not Found @nrwl/express : Not Found @nrwl/jest : 15.3.0 @nrwl/js : Not Found @nrwl/linter : 15.3.0 @nrwl/nest : Not Found @nrwl/next : Not Found @nrwl/node : Not Found @nrwl/nx-cloud : Not Found @nrwl/nx-plugin : Not Found @nrwl/react : Not Found @nrwl/react-native : Not Found @nrwl/rollup : Not Found @nrwl/schematics : Not Found @nrwl/storybook : Not Found @nrwl/web : Not Found @nrwl/webpack : Not Found @nrwl/workspace : Not Found typescript : 4.9.5 --------------------------------------- Local workspace plugins: --------------------------------------- Community plugins: ``` ### Failure Logs _No response_ ### Additional Information _No response_

title: NX Cloud runner fails to upload cache to AWS if running from docker
body: ### Current Behavior Running `yarn nx run-many --target=build --all` from local shell leads to uploading cache to aws successfully, but running the same command with same env variables from node-alpine docker image leads to failing to upload cache to AWS. ### Expected Behavior Nx will be able to upload cache when running from docker. ### GitHub Repo _No response_ ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Create repo with nx-cloud runner 2. Create dockerfile ``` FROM public.ecr.aws/docker/library/node:17-alpine AS builder WORKDIR /usr/src/app RUN apk add --no-cache python3 bash git openssh make build-base gcc COPY package.json yarn.lock ./ RUN --mount=type=cache,id=hdo-web-yarn-cache,target=/root/.yarn \ YARN_CACHE_FOLDER=/root/.yarn \ yarn install --frozen-lockfile ADD . . ARG APP_VERSION=dev ARG PUBLIC_URL="" ARG NX_BRANCH="" ENV REVISION="$APP_VERSION" ENV PUBLIC_URL="$PUBLIC_URL" ENV NX_BRANCH="$NX_BRANCH" RUN export NX_BRANCH="$NX_BRANCH" \ && export NX_VERBOSE_LOGGING=true \ && yarn nx report \ && NX_CLOUD_AUTH_TOKEN="XXX" \ yarn nx run-many --target=build --all ``` 3. Check NX logs where is says that it pushed the cache 4. Check NX Cloud. No builds are available there ### Nx Report ```shell #13 3.051 > NX Report complete - copy this into the issue template #13 3.051 #13 3.051 Node : 17.9.1 #13 3.051 OS : linux arm64 #13 3.051 yarn : 1.22.19 #13 3.051 #13 3.051 nx : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/jest : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/linter : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/workspace : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/cli : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/cypress : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/devkit : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/eslint-plugin-nx : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/js : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/react : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/storybook : 15.7.2 #13 3.051 @nrwl/tao : 15.7.2 #13 3.052 @nrwl/webpack : 15.7.2 #13 3.052 @nrwl/nx-cloud : 15.1.1 #13 3.052 typescript : 4.7.3 ``` ### Failure Logs _No response_ ### Additional Information I checked generated links and it seems that AWS signature is wrong if generated from docker: ``` SignatureDoesNotMatchThe request signature we calculated does not match the signature you provided. Check your key and signing method.AKIAZCDOVASOE4QJT27MAWS4-HMAC-SHA256 ```

title: Nx build: Derived tsconfig is not working when project has 0 dependencies.
body:
### Current Behavior

When building a lib with 0 dependencies, which uses a derived tsconfig.base the nx build commands gives an error:
`Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'paths')`.

This is because the derived tsconfig is not taken into account when building a lib that doesn't have any dependencies.

### Expected Behavior

When running nx build on a project without any dependencies I would expect that the `extends` property is still taken into account.

Also Nx build should succeed without any error in such a scenario.

### GitHub Repo

https://github.com/janwiebedroid/nx-tsconfig-bug/tree/main/nx-ts-config-bugs

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Ensure that there are no compiler options in packages/testlib1/tsconfig.lib.json
2. Run `nx build testlib1`
3. Error occurs

When running nx build on a project with dependencies it works:
1. Ensure that there are no compiler options in packages/testlib-with-deps/tsconfig.lib.json
2. Run `nx build testlib-with-deps`
3. No error occursn

### Nx Report

```shell
>  NX   Report complete - copy this into the issue template

   Node : 16.17.0
   OS   : win32 x64
   npm  : 8.15.0

   nx                      : 15.7.1
   @nrwl/linter            : 15.7.1
   @nrwl/workspace         : 15.7.1
   @nrwl/cli               : 15.7.1
   @nrwl/devkit            : 15.7.1
   @nrwl/eslint-plugin-nx  : 15.7.1
   @nrwl/js                : 15.7.1
   @nrwl/tao               : 15.7.1
   typescript              : 4.8.4
```


### Failure Logs

_No response_

### Additional Information

The issue seems to be in [check-dependencies.ts](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/packages/js/src/utils/check-dependencies.ts).

If there are 0 dependencies a temp tsconfig is never created.

title: Esbuild should support plugins

labels.name: scope: bundlers
labels.description: Issues related to webpack, rollup

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [x] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
<!-- What is the behavior that you would like to see introduced? -->
 
 Nx plugins primarily get target (build/lint/test) configurations from a json file `project.json`. 
 Which works in the majority of scenarios.
 
 However, the `esbuild` plugins API allows users to provide a setup function which is passed to the build API.
 https://esbuild.github.io/plugins/#finding-plugins
 
As at our current state Nx 15.7.0 we do not fully support this approach.
  
## Motivation
<!-- Why do you believe this behavior would be beneficial? -->
Initially, this came out of an issue: https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/14823
PR: to remove plugin in favour of doing it as a feature: https://github.com/nrwl/nx/pull/14997

## Suggested Implementation
<!-- How do you imagine this might work? -->
The prospective implementation would be similar to what @jaysoo highlighted. 
```ts
// esbuild.config.ts
export default {
  //...
  plugins: [require('foo-plugin')]
}
```
Additionally, should you provide configurations through `project.json` and `esbuild.config.ts` we would have a priority merging
For example priority would be
1. `esbuild.config.ts`
2. `project.json` configuration
3. Nx internal configuration
4. External configuration

## Alternate Implementations
<!-- How else do you imagine this might work? -->
Also support `.js` files
```js
// esbuild.config.js
module.exports = {
  // ...
  plugins: [require('foo-plugin')]
};
```

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [X] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
<!-- What is the behavior that you would like to see introduced? -->
Today, running @nrwl/web:file-server does not expose a few useful options of the underlying http-server:
* cache time (-c)
* gzip compression (-g)
* brotli compression (-b)

## Motivation
<!-- Why do you believe this behavior would be beneficial? -->
When doing live reloading, etc. these options probably don't make much sense.  But there are some use cases where they could.  One example, we want to build the app in CI, and then spin up a quick server to host a production-like application for testing.  Exposing those options with reasonable defaults would be useful in that scenario.

title: Add ability to specify library name not based on directory path using @nrwl/nest:library

labels.name: scope: node
labels.description: Issues related to Node, Express, NestJS support for Nx

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description

Using the following command, the following output is generated:

```ts
yarn nx generate @nrwl/nest:library item --directory=api/feature --no-interactive --dry-run

CREATE libs/api/feature/item/README.md
CREATE libs/api/feature/item/src/index.ts
CREATE libs/api/feature/item/tsconfig.json
CREATE libs/api/feature/item/tsconfig.lib.json
CREATE libs/api/feature/item/project.json
UPDATE tsconfig.base.json
CREATE libs/api/feature/item/.eslintrc.json
CREATE libs/api/feature/item/jest.config.ts
CREATE libs/api/feature/item/tsconfig.spec.json
CREATE libs/api/feature/item/src/lib/api-feature-item.module.ts
```

However, the `module` file that is created contains the directory path name. But what if I just wanted it to be called `item.module.ts` rather than `api-feature-item.module.ts`?

It doesn't look like this is possible with the current implementation of the CLI.

## Motivation

Following this NX implementation [here](https://gist.github.com/trungk18/7ef8766cafc05bc8fd87be22de6c5b12), where every lib has a `feature`, `data-access`, `utils` sub-libs, it would be convenient to have shorter file names within these sub-libs. It makes so sense to have such long names IMO, since the directory paths are different, there would be no collisions.

It's not only the file names that are extra long but the class names within these files follow the same structure, only using camel case. (i.e., `class ApiFeatureItemController` for example)

## Suggested Implementation

Add an additional flag to the CLI, something like `--filename`:

```ts
yarn nx generate @nrwl/nest:library item --directory=api/feature --filename=item --no-interactive --dry-run
```
