title: Support Cypress Component Testing with Next.js

labels.name: scope: testing tools
labels.description: Issues related to Cypress / Jest support in Nx

body:
- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
Cypress Component Testing seems like it would be a very useful workflow, but unfortunately Nx doesn't seem to support it for Next.js projects.

Running a command like: 
```
nx g @nrwl/react:cypress-component-configuration --project=my-project --build-target=web:build
```
_(by the way, the [official documentation](https://nx.dev/packages/react/generators/cypress-component-configuration) states to run `react:cypress-component-project` instead of `-configuration`, which is incorrect)_

results in this errors:

```
 ERROR  The provided build target, web:build, uses the '@nrwl/next:build' executor.
But only the follow executors are allowed
- @nrwl/webpack:webpack
```

## Motivation

I was pretty excited to use Cypress Component Testing to have a visual debugging environment for UI component tests, and Nx seemed to support it, but I was frustrated to discover the support was only for vanilla React projects, not Next.js.

## Suggested Implementation

Since Nx already supports Cypress Component Testing and Cypress Component already [supports Next.js](https://docs.cypress.io/guides/component-testing/overview#Supported-Frameworks), it seems like there's only a small missing piece required to allow it to use a Next build executor instead of Webpack.

## Alternate Implementations

If it's already possible to do this and I just haven't figured it out, extending the documentation to explain what to do for this use case would be extremely helpful.

title: Nx "run-many build  --parallel" with Angular apps/libs projects takes a lot of CPU and Nx service is stopped...

labels.name: scope: angular
labels.description: Issues related to Angular support in Nx

body:
### Current Behavior

We have a Nx workspace with the following setup:

- 4 Angular applications
- 4 Angular libraries used in the above apps
- 1 storybook-host (library project, to show all storybooks)

![graph-anon](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4053092/212318565-538cf8ae-e547-4406-88bb-6e0ea9f37374.jpg)

When running the command to build all the apps/libs at once (minus the storybook),  the process takes a lot of CPU (almost 100%), and regularly  crashes on our CI/CD platform....

The crash almost always appears when building application "app4" ( and sometimes, but more rarely, "app3" or "app2").
The rest of applications and libraries gets build without errors most of the time.

Here is the relevant command :
```
> nx run-many --target build --parallel 4 --verbose --exclude storybook-host


 >  NX   Running target build for 8 project(s):

    - lib1
    - app4
    - app1
    - lib4
    - lib3
    - lib2
    - app3
    - app2

```

**Environment:** 

The build is launched on an **AWS Codebuild machine**, with the following steps:

- **Image**: aws/codebuild/standard:5.0
- **Environment type**: Linux
- **Compute Power**: 7 GB memory, 4 vCPUs (which is a lot imho...)

- **Angular** v14.2.10
- **Nx** v15.1.0


### Expected Behavior

The build should be successfull

### Github Repo

_No response_

### Steps to Reproduce

I cannot really provide repro steps...

body:
### Current Behavior

Currently pnpm is resolving two different versions of rxjs in a repo with nestjs 9.

- nestjs 9 - use rxjs 7
- nx uses rxjs 6

after install, the pnpm lock file will have similar content

```
  /rxjs/6.6.7:
    resolution: {integrity: sha512-hTdwr+7yYNIT5n4AMYp85KA6yw2Va0FLa3Rguvbpa4W3I5xynaBZo41cM3XM+4Q6fRMj3sBYIR1VAmZMXYJvRQ==}
    engines: {npm: '>=2.0.0'}

      tslib: 1.14.1
    dev: true

    resolution: {integrity: sha512-F2+gxDshqmIub1KdvZkaEfGDwLNpPvk9Fs6LD/MyQxNgMds/WH9OdDDXOmxUZpME+iSK3rQCctkL0DYyytUqMg==}
    dependencies:
      tslib: 2.4.1
```

I added a package `nest-pino` that uses specific rxjs 7 api and that's where the issue started to show up.
There could be more areas where having two different major versions is a problem but its just the one i happened to run into

### Expected Behavior

Nx should not be using a different major version of rxjs from nestjs ^9

### Github Repo

https://github.com/lwhiteley/rxjs-repro.git

### Steps to Reproduce

- clone the mentioned 
- run `pnpm i`
- run `pnpm nx serve core-api`
- run `curl localhost:3333/health`

Please note that the error happens in the LogInterceptor for nestjs-pino

commenting this line, should allow the api to work but it is still required for the setup

see: https://github.com/lwhiteley/rxjs-repro/blob/main/apps/core-api/src/helpers/configureLogging.ts

title: do not install e2e dependencies when using --no-e2e

labels.name: scope: testing tools
labels.description: Issues related to Cypress / Jest support in Nx

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
I'm facing an issue that is affecting a proposal of a new codebase in the company I work which has strict download policies.

when using `npx create-nx-workspace my-workspace --preset=angular --e2e=none` I was expecting that cypress won't be installed (I am proposing on the place I work to allow downloads, but for the moment I need to start working on code) until we got the approval.


## Description
<!-- What is the behavior that you would like to see introduced? -->

if using 
```
$ npx create-nx-workspace --e2e=none
```

the workspace should not have in the list of dependencies cypress. 

the user later on can add cypress (when is available and allowed in my case) I should be able to run the required generator to run Cypress tests

## Motivation
<!-- Why do you believe this behavior would be beneficial? -->

in certain workplaces that run artifactory, you won't be able to download the binaries of (for example) cypress. this will prevent Nx to break in situations where there's no need of e2e, or, in my case, to break while proposing the use Nx for future company projects. Once the situation with cypress is fixed, I can just run the generator

## Suggested Implementation
<!-- How do you imagine this might work? -->

if I run 
```
$ npx create-nx-workspace --e2e=none
```

cypress won't be listed on the list of dependencies in the package.json of the project, and the installation of the workspace won't be breaking because it can't download the binaries in places where have strict download policies.

## Alternate Implementations
<!-- How else do you imagine this might work? -->

we could potentially provide a binary path to create-nx-workspace where it can pick the binaries for cypress:

```
$ npx create-nx-workspace --e2e=cypress --e2e-setup-binary=/c/users/myuser/downloads/cypressSetup.exe
```
in that way, we can tell cypress to take the binary from that path instead of the default one.

title: Nx's default `--parallel` value not correctly set to 3

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
### Current Behavior

If the `--parallel` tag is not explicitly set, then it defaults to `undefined`, although the documentation specifies that 3 is the default value.

### Expected Behavior

It should be defaulted to 3, or the documentation should be updated to say the default value is `undefined`, meaning sequential execution

### Github Repo

https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/packages/nx/src/utils/command-line-utils.ts#L168-L180

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run `nx run-many --target=lint --all`, without the `--parallel` tag.
2. All projects are linted sequentially.

### Nx Report

```shell
NA
```


### Failure Logs

```shell
NA
```


### Additional Information

I believe the problem lies within this snippet:
https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/packages/nx/src/utils/command-line-utils.ts#L168-L180

If `args['parallel']` is `undefined`, which it is when it’s not specified, then `nxArgs['parallel']` is not set and defaults to `undefined` too.

I've tested this by adding this line directly below the snippet above:
```
	output.note({
		title: `Run with args.parallel being '${args['parallel']}', so nxArgs.parallel is set to '${nxArgs['parallel']}'`,
	});
```

Running `nx run-many --target=lint --all` on my repository (or any nx repository for that matter) gives:
```
>  NX   NOTE  Run with args.parallel being 'undefined', so nxArgs.parallel is set to 'undefined'
```

I can create a PR, but I need to know the Nx team's decision. Do you want this `parallel` value to default to 3 or do you want to update the documentation to match the current behaviour?

title: Generated jest configs should have `collectCoverageFrom` set

labels.name: scope: testing tools
labels.description: Issues related to Cypress / Jest support in Nx

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
Currently when running e.g. `nx test project-a --codeCoverage`, it outputs a folder under `coverage` with an `index.html` that has the detailed code coverage stats.

I would expect the code coverage only to include the nested package that I ran code coverage on, but it displays coverage for the whole monorepo.

By adding `collectCoverageFrom: ['**/*.{ts,tsx}']` to the jest config, I was able to only see relevant files for a e.g. Nextjs project in this case.

## Motivation
Clearer path to work with code coverage

## Suggested Implementation
In my opinion, `nx` should have this set by default with the correct file extensions defined.

## Alternate Implementations
N/A

title: Synchronize React versions across official React-dependent Plugins

labels.name: blocked: retry with latest
labels.description: Retry with latest release or head.

labels.name: scope: react
labels.description: Issues related to React support for Nx

body:
- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
I created a fresh workspace with NX 15.0.4 that has a dashboard app (React), and two consumer-facing apps (one for mobile with Expo, and one for web with NextJS). 

Each plugin that generated the code (@nrwl/react, @nrwl/expo, @nrwl/next) relies on different React/ReactNative versions. While I understand that some devs like to use the latest stable versions, my priorities are simplicity and robustness. 

It would be great if NX's official plugins could generate apps/libs that use a single, lowest common React/ReactNative version across official NX plugins that use those dependencies. Upgrading automatically across the workspace whenever the lowest common React/ReactNative version increases would also be good.

## Motivation
Increase robustness and code simplicity for those devs that don't need the latest versions of React/ReactNative.

## Suggested Implementation
Add a flag in `nx.json` called `pluginsMustUseLowestCommonReact`. Then any plugin that depends on React/ReactNative reflects this in the code it generates (especially official plugins). The affected plugins would be: `@nrwl/react`, `@nrwl/react-native`, `@nrwl/expo`, `@nrwl/next`.

The flag could be set when creating workspaces: `npx create-nx-workspace@latest myorg --lowest-common-react`.

title: Accidentally publishing code on `nx.app` is way too easy
body:
My company considers my front-end repository, reasonably, to be confidential intellectual property. Yesterday when trying out `nx` for the first time I very narrowly avoided publishing my IP to the internet (i.e., to [anyone with a (free) nx.app account](https://nx.dev/nx-cloud/set-up/add-nx-cloud#connecting-your-workspace-to-your-nx-cloud-account)) by clicking "Yes" on this innocent-sounding default option during setup:

```
? Enable distributed caching to make your CI faster
  (Use arrow keys)
❯ Yes I want faster builds
  No
```

Frankly, it's nuts that with one keystroke here I could post my code to the public internet without any setup or registration. It never occurred to me that a build tool might do that. 

This default option during setup is the worst offender, but the `connect-to-nx-cloud` option is equally dangerous. The general point here is that it should not be trivially easy for me (or a junior colleague, say) to accidentally publish my private code to an unknown server.

`nx` has a financial incentive to entice me into the cloud build system. (You can tell that the marketing department wrote the option "Yes I want faster builds".) That's fine, and cloud build sounds like an awesome tool that I would probably be happy to pay for -- but not without understanding the implications first! Opting me in by default with no warning is irresponsible, if not outright sneaky.

Here are a few possible (non-mutually-exclusive) mitigations:
1. Default to "No", not "Yes", during setup
2. Add some red warning text next to the default option (`"Warning: this will publish your code to nx.app. Read more ..."`)
3. Add a confirmation screen after selecting "Yes" but before actually publishing code
4. Require some minimal account setup on `nx.app` (!)
5. Make the default `nx.app` account private, not public (!)
6. Read from an envar (`NX_CLOUD=false`) or an option in `nx.json` that disables cloud access (so no one on my team can accidentally use the command line flag to turn it on)

`nx` is super cool, and I appreciate convenience as much as the next dev, but until there are safety rails in place to prevent me or a colleague from exposing our company IP, I can't use it.

title: Cannot find tsconfig.base.json when generating plugin
[Nest] Library Generator does not generate `project.json` file

labels.name: blocked: retry with latest
labels.description: Retry with latest release or head.

labels.name: scope: node
labels.description: Issues related to Node, Express, NestJS support for Nx

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->

## Current Behavior
<!-- What is the behavior that currently you experience? -->

When i create a new `nrwl/nest - library` using the console, like this:

```bash
npx nx generate @nrwl/nest:library core --no-interactive --dry-run
```

no `project.json` file is generated, although the `standaloneConfig` flag is set to `true` by default.

The output generated by the `dry-run` looks as follows

```bash
CREATE libs/core/README.md
CREATE libs/core/src/index.ts
CREATE libs/core/tsconfig.json
CREATE libs/core/tsconfig.lib.json
UPDATE workspace.json
UPDATE tsconfig.base.json
CREATE libs/core/.eslintrc.json
UPDATE package.json
CREATE libs/core/jest.config.ts
CREATE libs/core/tsconfig.spec.json
CREATE libs/core/src/lib/core.module.ts
```

The configuration for this library is, however, put into the `workspace.json` file at the project root directory.

## Expected Behavior
<!-- What is the behavior that you expect to happen? -->
<!-- Is this a regression? .i.e Did this used to be the behavior at one point?  -->

I would expect to have a `project.json` file in my generated library, however, instead everything is written to the `workspace.json` file at the project root

## Steps to Reproduce
<!-- Help us help you by making it easy for us to reproduce your issue! -->

<!-- Can you reproduce this on https://github.com/nrwl/nx-examples? -->
<!-- If so, open a PR with your changes and link it below. -->

<!-- Remove this line -->
Simply run

```bash
npx nx generate @nrwl/nest:library core --no-interactive --dry-run
```
and inspect the dry-run output.

title: Don't use `identity-obj-proxy` by default in the jest resolver

labels.name: scope: testing tools
labels.description: Issues related to Cypress / Jest support in Nx

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [ x ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
<!-- What is the behavior that you would like to see introduced? -->

Allow the ability to handle `.css`, `.scss`,`.sass`,`.less`, `.styl` extensions rather than early exit in the default `@nrwl/jest/plugins/resolver` with `identity-obj-proxy`.

## Motivation
<!-- Why do you believe this behavior would be beneficial? -->

Using `@vanilla-extract` requires a `jest-transform` of the `css` files but it' not possible to handle/transform them because the default nx resolver catches all `css` files.

## Suggested Implementation
<!-- How do you imagine this might work? -->

The resolver logic already checks the resolver options which could be used to opt out of `identify-obj-proxy`

## Alternate Implementations
<!-- How else do you imagine this might work? -->

Don't default to `identity-obj-proxy` and instead provide that as boilerplate config which would be easier to discover/change

title: graph: `include` & `exclude` params being ignored

labels.name: scope: misc
labels.description: Misc issues

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->

## Current Behavior
<!-- What is the behavior that currently you experience? -->

Running 

```
nx graph --focus=todos-feature-main --exclude=project-one,project-two
``` 

correctly focuses on `todos-feature-main` **but does not exclude projects** `project-one` and `project-two`.

## Expected Behavior
I expect both projects `project-one` and `project-two` to not be highlighted/visible/selected

## Steps to Reproduce

```
git clone git@github.com:nrwl/nx-examples.git
cd nx-examples
npm i
nx graph --focus=cart --exclude=shared-header
```

Basically whatever I define for `--include` or `--exclude` is not being considered when rendering the graph.
The only param that works is `--focus`.

title: In an app bundle: class properties with constructor assignment result in additional void 0 assignment

labels.name: scope: react
labels.description: Issues related to React support for Nx

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->

## Current Behavior
**Update**: I've narrowed it down to something else (initially, I thought it had to do with an exclamation mark on the property).

I have code looking something like this in an app project:
```ts
class Foo {
    public foo: number;

    public constructor() {
        this.foo = 2;
    }
}
```

When I use the **dev-server** and when I **build** the app, I will get this in the bundle:

```js
class Foo {
  constructor() {
    this.foo = void 0;
    this.foo = 2;
  }
}
```

Aside from not-needed code, this by itself is no problem, but in certain situations this can be a problem, for example if the super call is supposed to assign the value.

This does not happen in other setups (outside of nx) and even when building a library with such a class:

```js
class Foo {
  constructor() {
    this.foo = 2;
  }
}
```

It has the same problem if I define the class in a library and import that library in an app of the same monorepo.

<!-- What is the behavior that currently you experience? -->

## Expected Behavior

I would have expected the app bundle to not set an (unneeded) undefined value.

I can see how this logic would be useful in some situations (for iterating properties?), but that causes issues when the assignment happens after other code is run, which might already set the property. Even if this is intended, it's currently not consistent

<!-- What is the behavior that you expect to happen? -->
<!-- Is this a regression? .i.e Did this used to be the behavior at one point?  -->

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a react app (other apps will probably do as well)
2. Add a class as seen above and run it on a dev-server or build it => you'll see a void 0 assignment.
3. Create a publishable ts library and export the above class from it
4. Build the library, check the dist folder for the generated javascript code => no void 0 assignment

I'm honestly not sure if this is related to nx or maybe swc or whatever transpiler is being used by the app setup.

<!-- Help us help you by making it easy for us to reproduce your issue! -->

<!-- Can you reproduce this on https://github.com/nrwl/nx-examples? -->
<!-- If so, open a PR with your changes and link it below. -->
<!-- If not, please provide a minimal Github repo -->

title: node_modules symlinks do not point to the dist folder

labels.name: scope: misc
labels.description: Misc issues

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->

## Current Behavior
<!-- What is the behavior that currently you experience? -->

When performing a `yarn install` with the default `package.json#workspaces` configuration the Symlinks created in the `node_modules` folder points to the project directory and not the `dist` directory.

## Expected Behavior

We should be able to define the `dist` folder where the build output is located so `yarn install` symlink the `dist` folder.

## Steps to Reproduce

### Create a new NX Workspace

```bash
$ npx create-nx-workspace@latest
```

### Generate two Typescript libraries

```bash
$ nx g @nrwl/js:lib lib-1
$ nx g @nrwl/js:lib lib-2
```

### Import lib-2 into lib-1

```typescript
// packages/lib-2/src/index.ts

import * as lib2 from '@myorg/lib-2';
```

### Build lib-1

```bash
$ nx build lib-1
```


<!-- Help us help you by making it easy for us to reproduce your issue! -->

<!-- Can you reproduce this on https://github.com/nrwl/nx-examples? -->
<!-- If so, open a PR with your changes and link it below. -->
<!-- If not, please provide a minimal Github repo -->
<!-- At the very least, provide as much detail as possible to help us reproduce the issue -->

<!-- Remove this line -->

### Workaround

Currently in the `package.json` folder we change the workspaces configurtation to the `dist` folder.

```json
{
  "workspaces": [
    "dist/**"
  ]
}
```

Symlinks works but we have to:
- Run `yarn`
- Build projects
- Run `yarn` again to get the symlinks

### Environment
<!-- It's important for us to know the context in which you experience this behavior! -->

title: @nrwl/nest:application schematic doesn't support --strict flag

labels.name: scope: node
labels.description: Issues related to Node, Express, NestJS support for Nx

body:
## Current Behavior
When I run the most recent @nrwl/nest:application schematic and pass the --strict flag, the command fails with the error below.  It appears that it is impossible to generate a nest application in strict mode using the @nrwl schematic, even though the @nest schematic supports it. 

## Expected Behavior
Generating a new nest application in strict mode should be supported by the schematic and should likely be the default, like it is with Angular applications.  Additionally, strict mode should likely be the default for the @nrwl/nest:library schematic (though that one does currently support the flag).

## Steps to Reproduce
PR demonstrating issue on https://github.com/nrwl/nx-examples at [https://github.com/nrwl/nx-examples/pull/234](https://github.com/nrwl/nx-examples/pull/234).  

1. Check out the branch on the PR above and install dependencies
2. Run the schematic command with `nx generate @nrwl/nest:application TestApp --no-interactive --strict`
3. See that it doesn't recognize the --strict flag

### Failure Logs
```

title: Environment to disable NxCloud
body:
- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
Working with Nx Private Cloud you can have situations where there are problems with the Nx Private Cloud
In these situations build times increase manyfold as all cacheable requests will wait 10s before timing out requests to Nx Cloud
If the functionality of the --no-cloud CLI option could be achieved through an environment variable - e.g. NX_NO_CLOUD - then this problem could be alleviated while solving the problem in Nx Cloud by setting this environment variable in the CI/CD and/or locally at a developer.

Likewise it could be useful to have NX_SKIP_NX_CACHE to skip both local and global cache like the --skip-nx-cache CLI option.

## Motivation
It can be used to make quick temporary fix for annoying problem.

## Suggested Implementation

if NX_NO_CLOUD environment variable is set all nx commands should be invoked as if --no-cloud was present on the command line.

While implementing this it could be a good idea to introduce NX_SKIP_NX_CACHE to cause all nx commands to be invoked as if --skip-nx-cache was present on the command line

## Alternate Implementations

title: `@nrwl/webpack` breaks jest by exporting `.d.ts` files from `index.js`

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->

## Current Behavior
<!-- What is the behavior that currently you experience? -->

Tests utilizing the `@nrwl/webpack` package fail because the `index.js` file in the built javascript is attempting to export two `schema.d.ts` files. I'm getting this in my unit tests for my own generators that extend the react and expo generators.

I was able to address this in my original repo by applying this patch:

```patch
diff --git a/index.js b/index.js
index 222c2849d7855ee4a8ff0f23525ddc7957f10b17..8d019a925e3b1b7ed24634c0be5008b797595455 100644
--- a/index.js
+++ b/index.js
@@ -6,6 +6,4 @@ tslib_1.__exportStar(require("./src/generators/webpack-project/webpack-project")
-tslib_1.__exportStar(require("./src/executors/dev-server/schema"), exports);
 tslib_1.__exportStar(require("./src/executors/dev-server/dev-server.impl"), exports);
 tslib_1.__exportStar(require("./src/executors/webpack/lib/normalize-options"), exports);
-tslib_1.__exportStar(require("./src/executors/webpack/schema"), exports);
 tslib_1.__exportStar(require("./src/executors/webpack/webpack.impl"), exports);
 //# sourceMappingURL=index.js.map
```

## Expected Behavior
<!-- What is the behavior that you expect to happen? -->
<!-- Is this a regression? .i.e Did this used to be the behavior at one point?  -->

Tests including `@nrwl/webpack` or its descendants should not fail (and `.js` files should not be attempting to export typescript)

## Steps to Reproduce
<!-- Help us help you by making it easy for us to reproduce your issue! -->

Here's a minimal test that reproduces the issue. Also can be seen in [this repo created with create-nx-plugin](https://github.com/NikkiDelRosso/repro-nx-webpack-schema-bug).
```typescript
import { normalizePluginPath } from '@nrwl/webpack';

describe('@nrwl/webpack normalizePluginPath', () => {
  it('should return a defined value', async () => {
    expect(normalizePluginPath("test", "test")).toBeDefined();
  });
});
```

Running this test using `npx nx test test` results in the following error.

<!-- Can you reproduce this on https://github.com/nrwl/nx-examples? -->
<!-- If so, open a PR with your changes and link it below. -->
<!-- If not, please provide a minimal Github repo -->
<!-- At the very least, provide as much detail as possible to help us reproduce the issue -->

### Failure Logs
<!-- Please include any relevant log snippets or files here. -->


```
  ● Test suite failed to run

    Cannot find module './src/executors/dev-server/schema' from '../../node_modules/@nrwl/webpack/index.js'

    Require stack:
      /Users/devin/repro-nx-webpack-schema-bug/node_modules/@nrwl/webpack/index.js
      src/test.spec.ts


    However, Jest was able to find:
    	'src/executors/dev-server/schema.d.ts'
    	'src/executors/dev-server/schema.json'

    You might want to include a file extension in your import, or update your 'moduleFileExtensions', which is currently ['ts', 'js', 'html'].

    See https://jestjs.io/docs/configuration#modulefileextensions-arraystring

      at Resolver._throwModNotFoundError (../../node_modules/jest-runtime/node_modules/jest-resolve/build/resolver.js:491:11)
      at Object.<anonymous> (../webpack/index.ts:3:1)
```

title: @nrwl/node:webpack fileReplacements aren't replaced before build

labels.name: scope: node
labels.description: Issues related to Node, Express, NestJS support for Nx

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->

## Current Behavior
When I run build configuration with `fileReplacements` set, the files aren't replaced before the build. So the application is built with the previous files (the ones that should be replaced) and not with the new ones.

## Expected Behavior
The files should be replaced before the build. 

## Steps to Reproduce
This problem is mostly visible when using gitignored environment files. See the example repository:

https://github.com/junekpavel/nx-node-filereplacements-demo/blob/main/apps/demo/project.json

We have gitignored `environment.local.ts` file which is reexported by `environment.ts`.  And in production configuration, we're using `fileReplacements` to replace `environment.ts` file with `environment.production.ts`.

Now if you don't have `environment.local.ts` file created and run :
```
nx run demo:build:production
```

You get the following error:
```
ERROR in ./apps/demo/src/environments/environment.ts:1:15
TS2307: Cannot find module './environment.local' or its corresponding type declarations.
  > 1 | export * from './environment.local';
      |               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    2 |
``` 

Which means the file wasn't replaced before the build was triggered. But I would expect the file get replaced first, so the build would run only with `environment.production.ts`. 

This is mostly problem in the CI where the local environment file never exists.

And just for example, we use the exact same practice for setting environments for Angular applications (with `@angular-devkit/build-angular:server` and `@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser` executors) and everything works fine.

```

title: `create-nx-workspace` checks for `insideRepo` fail if actually inside a git repo

labels.name: scope: misc
labels.description: Misc issues

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->

## Current Behavior
<!-- What is the behavior that currently you experience? -->
I have a fairly specific use case where my `preset` generator does take care of `git` initialization for me. It does so so that I can automate setting up a few other things that require a `git` repo to already exist.

Before [this PR](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/pull/11633) I think this behavior worked fine. After this PR merged (so since v14.6.0), I am now getting an error and pre-mature exit of workspace generation when a git repo already exists.

## Expected Behavior
<!-- What is the behavior that you expect to happen? -->
<!-- Is this a regression? .i.e Did this used to be the behavior at one point?  -->
Workspace generation should continue gracefully and simply output a message warning that git initialization was skipped.

This is likely a regression after https://github.com/nrwl/nx/pull/11633.

## Steps to Reproduce
<!-- Help us help you by making it easy for us to reproduce your issue! -->

<!-- Can you reproduce this on https://github.com/nrwl/nx-examples? -->
<!-- If so, open a PR with your changes and link it below. -->
<!-- If not, please provide a minimal Github repo -->
<!-- At the very least, provide as much detail as possible to help us reproduce the issue -->

I'm experiencing this issue while testing `@chiubaka/genesis@0.1.1`. You can run `npm install -g @chiubaka/genesis`, then run `genesis @proj/test -d "Test for insideRepo issue" --skip-github` to reproduce the error.

Otherwise, you can probably just create a new directory, run `git init`, and then attempt to run `create-nx-workspace` inside of it.

### Failure Logs
<!-- Please include any relevant log snippets or files here. -->
```
node:events:491
      throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
      ^

Error: spawn /bin/sh ENOENT
    at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (node:internal/child_process:283:19)
    at onErrorNT (node:internal/child_process:478:16)
    at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:83:21)
Emitted 'error' event on ChildProcess instance at:
    at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (node:internal/child_process:289:12)
    at onErrorNT (node:internal/child_process:478:16)
    at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:83:21) {

title: nx-plugin: create a generator which creates a generator wrapping an existing generator
body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [X] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))

## Description
<!-- What is the behavior that you would like to see introduced? -->

I want to see introduced a generator (probably supplied by `nx-plugin`) that would create a generator that would wrap an existing generator.

The generated generator should not create any additional behavior by default other than calling the wrapped generator.
The schema should be reused from the wrapped generator:
* in the `.d.ts` schema, it should `extend` the wrapped generator's schema
* in the `.json` schema, it should copy all properties of the wrapped generator's schema

## Motivation
<!-- Why do you believe this behavior would be beneficial? -->

Creating a custom generator that wraps an existing one is, in my experience and as far as I've seen so far from places like the nrwl slack workspace, one of the most common use cases of creating a generator.

You want to reuse an existing generator's behavior, but add your custom shticks that are relevant to your project, like altering configuration or some files.

This isn't very difficult, but requires some knowledge about generators from the get-go:
1. How to import an existing generator
2. What's the proper way (or at least A way) of reusing the generator's schema, both `.d.ts` and `.json`.

This is something that takes time to perform, and is also something that's difficult for devs without prior experience in implementing custom generators.

Having a generator that would create all the required boilerplate would:
1. Save time when creating a new generator
2. Will be a living source of documentation of how to implement this behavior.

Due to the two reasons above, it would also make creating custom generators even more accessible, since it cuts down on even more friction devs have when thinking about implementing a custom generator.

## Suggested Implementation
<!-- How do you imagine this might work? -->

```sh
yarn nx generate @nrwl/nx-plugin:wrapping-generator --name=react-application --project=my-local-workspace-plugin --generator=@nrwl/react:application
```

Output:

## TS Schema definition

It should create an interface which extends the wrapped generator schema.
Potential edge case would be getting the name of the exported interface from the wrapped generator.
In nrwl generators it's exported as `Schema`, but it might not be the case.
Some typescript AST introspection and heuristics might be required to implement this properly.

```ts
// schema.d.ts
import {Schema as WrappedApplicationSchema} from '@nrwl/react/src/generators/application/schema';

export interface ApplicationSchema extends WrappedApplicationSchema { }
```

## JSON Schema definition

The JSON schema properties should be copied over from the wrapped generator schema

## Implementation

The generated implementation would import the generator, and call it. This would be a starting point for developers to add their own customizations.

```ts
import wrappedApplicationGenerator from '@nrwl/react/src/generators/application/generator';
import {ApplicationSchema} from './schema';

export default async function applicationGenerator(tree: Tree, schema: ApplicationSchema): Promise<GeneratorCallback> {
  const callback = await wrappedApplicationGenerator(tree, schema);
  return () => callback();
}
```

## Alternate Implementations
<!-- How else do you imagine this might work? -->

IDK honestly, would be happy to hear feedback and any alternative thoughts.

## Sidenote

Another one of the points of friction for creating custom generators is that schema normalization applied by the generator internally is not exposed outside, which means that devs implementing custom generators have to compromise when implementing their code: They either cut down on properties passed down to wrapped generators, or implement a lot of the normalizations manually, to be able to handle the generator output properly (file names, etc).

Exporting the normalized schema, as well as the `normalizeSchema` function, as a standard of all (official) generators would remove this compromise since you'll be able to more easily handle different inputs to generators.

title: Optimize e2e web servers

labels.description: Issues related to Cypress / Jest support in Nx

body:
- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
It should be possible for executors to specify "before all" and "after all" hooks, which are executed once before / after running a executor for projects with `nx run-many` and `nx affected` commands.

## Motivation
My usecase is that i have a executor to run playwright tests for a project, which requires a dev server to be started before running tests. At the moment the dev server is started each time the executor is running. It would be i nice optimization if the dev server could be started once and the reused for all playwright tests. This is just one example of many where some kind of set up or tear down logic which can be done once accros all executions

title: Allow the projects nx affected considers to be limited by acceptting --tags argument

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description

run `deploy` target for all affected projects who are tag with either `app` or `service`

```shell
$ nx affected --target=deploy --tag=app --tag=service
```

run `deploy` target for all affected projects who are tag with both `finance` and `service`

```shell
$ nx affected --target=deploy --tags=finance,service
```


## Motivation

```
name: Build and Release all changed Desktop Apps

on:
  push:
    branch:
      - master


concurrency:
  group: ${{ github.workflow }}-${{ github.ref }}
  cancel-in-progress: true

jobs:
  Release:
    name: Release Packages and Changelogs


    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
        with:
          # We need to fetch all branches and commits so that Nx affected has a base to compare against.
          fetch-depth: 0
          persist-credentials: false


      - name: Derive appropriate SHAs for base and head for `nx affected` commands
        uses: nrwl/nx-set-shas@v2
        with:
          main-branch-name: master

      - uses: ./pkg/ci/setup-tooling
        with:
          SetupCommand: ./setup.sh

      - uses: ./pkg/ci/setup-yarn

      - uses: ./pkg/ci/setup-node-ghpr
        with:
          NodeAuthToken: ${{secrets.BOT_TOKEN}}

      - run: just nx affected --target=release --tags=app,desktop
        env:
          GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.BOT_TOKEN }}
          GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL: ${{secrets.BOT_GIT_EMAIL}}
          GIT_AUTHOR_NAME: ${{secrets.BOT_GIT_NAME}}
          GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL: ${{secrets.BOT_GIT_EMAIL}}
          GIT_COMMITTER_NAME: ${{secrets.BOT_GIT_NAME}}
```


## Suggested Implementation

no idea

## Alternate Implementations

not interested in alternatives.

title: Cache busting!

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
As a wise man once said "There are two things difficult in software programming, naming, cache invalidation, and count by 0 errors". 

## Description
We currently use Nx to cache our builds so that references to libs are not required to be rebuilt if there are no changes to its source. The problem is that every time something has to be rebuilt it stores a new cache and keeps the original. We tried to invest some time into removing older cache items but we found that we were reverse engineering your cache system.
What I would really love to see is Nx cache invalidate itself.

## Motivation
Cache invalidation is required (it takes up a lot of disk space when apps are 500mb x 1000s of cache folders)

## Suggested Implementation
Psuedo code....
if (cacheIsInvalid) {
  removeOldCache() // This is the part I believe to be missing
  runBuildAndCreateNewCache()
}

title: Invert the unsafe behaviour of default arguments being forwarded to commands

labels.name: scope: misc
labels.description: Misc issues

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [x] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
<!-- What is the behavior that you would like to see introduced? -->

A follow up from closed issue #7752 



## Motivation
<!-- Why do you believe this behavior would be beneficial? -->

The current behaviour is undesireable as it is common to re-use the same target/executor such as run-commands (especially when using just nx core) and also is a security issue.

### Quoted from myself on #7752 

I'd really like to re-open this and discuss alternatives (including workspace wide configuration) for this. The default behaviour of forwarding all args to every command that is run (even dependencies) is highly undesirable and the needs to swap between "commands" and "command" with a verbose syntax just to escape the default behaviour isn't great. I'd argue there's even security concerns with this default behaviour but I'm not an expert.

If I want to run target "A" and know args to pass I want only target "A" to receive those args. Right now every dependent target receives the same args.

Concrete example: "nx run service:deploy --stack production --awsProfile service-deployer" --preview etc. Deploy targets are dependent upon "package" -> "build" -> "prepare" and if I'm using run-commands for any of those they are receiving the args I was using for the "deploy" target and failing.

The ONLY way to make sure this doesn't happen is to add "forwardAllArgs" to every command by default and explicitly opt-in to that behaviour instead. I think this is a much much safer default. Right now my dependencies are at least failing with "unknown args" but one day someone is going to have a stray option which does not have the semantic intention they issues the nx command with.

### Quoted from @klemenoslaj on #7752

I couldn't agree more. This really can be a security hazard.

Was there any progress on that?

To avoid breaking change I would at first I would recommend a global forwardAllArgs setting, to set the default value.

## Suggested Implementation
<!-- How do you imagine this might work? -->

1. Invert default behaviour of forwardAllArgs
2. Allow specifying on options for "command" and/or all "commands" rather than just on individual "commands" requiring verbose syntax to workaround


## Alternate Implementations
<!-- How else do you imagine this might work? -->

Unsure.

title: List  plugins hosted in internal artifactory by using the nx list.

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->
<!-- Use this issue type for concrete suggestions, otherwise, open a discussion type issue instead. -->

- [x] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
Since private artifactory hosts a few of the internal plugins that organizations typically use for NX, it would be beneficial to have NX cli list those plugins if the project has a configuration file pointing to a JSON URL that would list internal plugins. 

## Motivation
- In addition to core and community approved plugins, "nx list" would support plugins hosted internally and by third parties (based on config file in project). 
- This will help multiple teams across organization to reuse or enhance internally existing plugins instead of re-creating plugins for internal use (Increases re-usability of plugins within private artifactories).


## Suggested Implementation
Create a file named "nx-plugin.conf" at the root of the workspace project directory. 
To add functionality to parse the configuration file, perform a HTTP GET on the JSON URL specified in the configuration file, and STDOUT the JSON response. If file or URL is invalid, the script would not stdout `third party / internal plugins` to console. 

Rough Implementation is done in this [commit ](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/compare/master...ByteOPCode:nx:master).

## Alternate Implementations
While creating a project, adding a inquirer option to ask if the project has an additional upstream source for nx plugins, that they can use as a pointer for internal artifactory and write the URL  to `workspace.json / nx.json` and `nx list` would parse json file to get plugin list from the URL.

title: Support NestJS web servers that depend on applications of the Monorepo

labels.name: scope: node
labels.description: Issues related to Node, Express, NestJS support for Nx

body:
- [ ] I'd be willing to implement this feature ([contributing guide](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md))


## Description
In the project setup that I'm using, an Angular application is served via a NestJS web server. The NestJS web server uses `@nestjs/serve-static` to serve the static files of the Angular application.

There is a dependency between the web server and the Angular application. It makes only sense to deploy the web server with the newest version of the Angular application. If a change to the Angular application occurs, the web server should be marked as affected, because it depends on the application. 

I modeled this dependency via the `implicitDependencies` property of the web server `project.json`. However, I'm using the option `generatePackageJson` of `@nrwl/node:webpack` to generate a `package.json` for the docker build. Since the web server has an implicit dependency on the Angular application, all Angular libraries are included in the generated `package.json`.

I couldn't find my project setup in the nx documentation, so I'm unsure if this is the correct setup. 

## Motivation
The use case of a NestJS web server that serves applications of the Monorepo is a common use case and should be supported.

## Suggested Implementation
Support implicit dependencies between Angular applications and web servers that don't affect the `package.json` generation.

## Alternate Implementations
Extend the documentation and describe the preferred nx setup for a NestJS web server.

title: Unclear how to use the "sourceMap" or "declarationMap" option in TSConfig in the context of an NX monorepo
body:
### Documentation issue - [ ] Reporting a typo - [ ] Reporting a documentation bug - [x] Documentation improvement - [ ] Documentation feedback It seems like a pretty common use-case for NX is to publish a package to NPM from inside of an NX monorepo. However, it is unclear how to do so while simultaneously having the "sourceMap" or "declarationMap" option in the "tsconfig.json" file turned on. Please either document how to do this, or document that it is impossible as a limitation of the product.
### A More Detailed Explanation When publishing libraries to NPM, it's a nice quality-of-life improvement to use the "sourceMap" compiler option in the "tsconfig.json" file for the project. Doing this allows end-users who are consuming the library to be able to press F12 in VSCode (i.e. "jump to definition"), and instead of warping to the definitions stub (like normal), they are instead warped directly to the real source code. Under the hood, this works by publishing all of the source files to NPM alongside the compiled JavaScript files. And then VSCode uses the `.map` file to work its way backwards from the `.js` file to the appropriate `.ts` file. As an example, running `npx tsc` in my library directory of: ``` /Users/Zamiell/foo ``` Would create the following files: ``` /Users/Zamiell/foo/dist/index.d.ts.map /Users/Zamiell/foo/dist/index.js ``` The contents of `index.d.ts.map` are: ``` {"version":3,"file":"index.d.ts","sourceRoot":"","sources":["../src/index.ts"]} ``` And then, I publish both my "src" and "dist" directories to NPM, and everything works great. (i.e. by using the "files" key in the "package.json" file to specify what gets uploaded)
### Introducing NX However, when we try to do this in an NX monorepo, things break down. When we turn on the "sourceMap" compiler option, the maps point upwards into directories that don't exist. For example, say that I run `npx tsc` in the following folder: ``` /Users/Zamiell/nx-monorepo/packages/foo ``` It creates the following files, but this time they go to the monorepo root: ``` /Users/Zamiell/nx-monorepo/dist/packages/foo/index.d.ts.map /Users/Zamiell/nx-monorepo/dist/packages/foo/index.js ``` And in this case, the contents of `index.d.ts.map` are: ``` {"version":3,"file":"index.d.ts","sourceRoot":"","sources":["../../../packages/foo/src/index.ts"]} ``` Here, the root directory of the uploaded files to npm are `/Users/Zamiell/monorepo/dist/packages/foo`, so the "sources" property looks backwards into directories that don't exist on the computers of the end-users. It's unclear how to solve this problem: - If we manually add the `.ts` files after the compilation step, that doesn't help anything, because the `.d.ts.map` files are already created with the erroneous paths. - If we manually add the `.ts` files before the compilation, that doesn't help anything, because then all of the import statements break, as the paths to all of the libraries and what-not have changed. Is this problem solvable? Note that this isn't a problem with other monorepo tools, because it doesn't consolidate the `dist` directory like NX does.

  --nx-bail           Stop command execution after the first failed task                                                                                                                                      [boolean] [default: false]
  --nx-ignore-cycles  Ignore cycles in the task graph                                                                                                                                                         [boolean] [default: false]

Examples:
  affected --target=custom-target                         Run custom target for all affected projects
  affected --target=test --parallel=5                     Run tests in parallel
  affected --target=test --all                            Run the test target for all projects
  affected --target=test --files=libs/mylib/src/index.ts  Run tests for all the projects affected by changing the index.ts file
  affected --target=test --base=main --head=HEAD          Run tests for all the projects affected by the changes between main and HEAD (e.g., PR)
  affected --target=test --base=main~1 --head=main        Run tests for all the projects affected by the last commit on main

Find more information and examples at https://nx.dev/cli/affected

```

## Current Behavior
<!-- What is the behavior that currently you experience? -->
If I have a React application which depends on a buildable lib, and the "buildLibsFromSource" setting is set to false, then running `nx serve your-app` will not work because the dependent lib has not been built. Running `nx build your-app` will work properly. Changes to that lib will not cause the application to hot-reload.

## Current Behavior

running `npx nx run myApp:build:production --outputPath=apps/myApp/dist`
has different output depending on the directory I am in. When running from root, the `dist` output includes the `index.html` file. However when running from within `apps/myApp` the `index.html` is missing from `dist`. All other files are there as expected.


## Expected Behavior

title: NextJS serve executor depends on libs being located in `libsDir`

labels.name: scope: react
labels.description: Issues related to React support for Nx

body:
<!-- Please do your best to fill out all of the sections below! -->

## Current Behavior
When I create a NextJS application using the generator, then create a React lib using the generator, and then import a JSX from that React lib into the NextJS application, then `nx serve next-app` works fine.

However, if I place the React library in a folder other than the configured `libsDir` in `nx.json`, the build will fail with an error that it can't understand the JSX files in the React lib.

## Expected Behavior
Based on my experience with other kinds of applications in Nx (node, nest etc) I expected the build system for Next to be directory-structure agnostic. Basically as long as it's able to resolve the library, I expected the build to succeed.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Generate a NextJS application
2. Generate a React library
3. Import a JSX component from React lib into NextJS app
4. Change the value of "libsDir" in `nx.json` to some other value
5. `nx serve next-app`
6. Build fails

## Other Info
I took a look in the source code and it seems like the problem is happening here, where the webpack config depends on the value of `libsDir`:
https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/packages/next/src/utils/config.ts#L91

I'm not sure if this was done deliberately or whether it's actually necessary for things to work, but I figured I'd flag it.

title: Allow executors access to base (`_`) params

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
## Description

I would like executor to be able to access params that are passed without a flag. Example
```
nx run app:run base param
```

In executor options I would like to see 
```
{
  _: [ 'base', 'param' ]
}
```

## Motivation

In my [nx-serverless](https://github.com/Bielik20/nx-plugins/tree/master/packages/nx-serverless) plugin currently to run custom command one needs to run:

```
nx run app:sls --command 'invoke lokal'
```

It works, but looks and feels weird, especially with the `'`. I would love to provide functionality that would feel more familiar, and less forced. Consider alternative:

```
nx run app:sls invoke lokal
```

That looks and feels right. I am in the middle of working on improvement of my [nx-serverless](https://github.com/Bielik20/nx-plugins/tree/master/packages/nx-serverless) plugin which I would like to share with the community (https://github.com/nrwl/nx/issues/2670). Still I would love to have things like that covered before I present my results.

## Suggested Implementation

First step would be to either remove `_` from this array: https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/8435bdfb6fcc018a13a515a461cf4cbcf5869e1b/packages/workspace/src/command-line/utils.ts#L73
Or remove this line:
https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/8435bdfb6fcc018a13a515a461cf4cbcf5869e1b/packages/workspace/src/command-line/utils.ts#L92

This doesn't result in options with `_` but at least includes it inside `process.argv`. Because currently there is absolutely no way to access them.

I am open to work on a PR for that, but I would love to hear from you if you would even consider it. Maybe some explanation why those `_` are excluded in the first place?

## Alternate Implementations
...

title: Display message after Generator `printChanges` output in terminal screen
body:
## Description
As discussed in https://github.com/nrwl/nx/discussions/7287 I've been looking for a way to output additional information after a custom generator function has ran.

Currently if I try to console.log at the end of my generator function the log will be placed before the [`printChanges`](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/2f675f7577d8e919704dbbc39e99097c935c9be4/packages/tao/src/commands/generate.ts#L233) output

```
Test log from Generator

UPDATE angular.json
UPDATE nx.json
CREATE apps/test-app/README.md
UPDATE package.json
```

The main issue with this is that some generators can produced and update a lot of files which makes the changes log very long. Anything printed before this has a chance that it won't be seen by the user, thus losing the ability to alert them of additional steps they may need to take.

Creators can then have the power to log any useful information that will definitely be seen by the user.

```
UPDATE angular.json
UPDATE nx.json
CREATE apps/test-app/README.md
UPDATE package.json

Next steps:
* Register domain
* Create SSL Certificate
* Deploy ECS Server
```

## Suggested Implementation
Maybe the generator function could return a function that can be called after the `printChanges` method and before the check for `--dryRun`

title: Too aggressive in failing projects when using strictlyOrderedTargets

labels.name: scope: core
labels.description: core nx functionality

body:
## Description
When projects are related and a dependency fails, all projects that have yet to run are skipped and marked as failed, even if they don't depend on the failing project.

For example, assume four projects:
* one
* two
* three
* four

Via implicit dependencies, project "four" depends on project "two", and project "three" depends on project "one".

```
-----   -----
| 2 |   | 1 |
-----   -----
  |       |
-----   -----
| 4 |   | 3 |
-----   -----
```

This creates two silos with no dependencies between them.

Also, the "strictlyOrderedTargets" option is set to `true` in `nx.json` for the `@nrwl/workspace/tasks-runners/default` runner.

Now assume we run a target against all of them and that project "two" fails.

We'd fully expect project "four" to fail because a project upon which it depends failed. But there's no reason either "one" or "three" should fail, yet "three" will always fail because it is slotted to run after "two" because it has a dependency, even though that dependency is unrelated to the failure. *Nx short-circuits and fails everything yet to run, which is too aggressive.*

I have a sample repository at https://github.com/arabull/nx-ordered-failures that illustrates this behavior.

I'm filing this as a feature request as opposed to a bug because I can't in good faith argue that anything is broken. It's definitely sub-optimal, though.

## Motivation

I have a workspace with dozens of projects, many of which have pair dependencies like the pattern described above with one/three and two/four. In other words, I have a bunch of silos in my dependency tree with little to no crossover. If I get a failure in one of my dependencies within one of those silos, every single project that depends on another will fail.

Like so:

```
-----   -----   -----   -----   -----
| X |   | ✔️ |   | ✔️ |   | ✔️ |   | ✔️ |
-----   -----   -----   -----   -----
  |       |       |       |       |
-----   -----   -----   -----   -----
| X |   | X |   | X |   | X |   | X |
-----   -----   -----   -----   -----
```

In this example, we'd expect the depending project in the first silo to fail since its dependency failed, but there's no reason the rest of them should fail. But they do, without even running.

## Suggested Implementation

Unless a project's dependency fails, it should run and pass/fail on its own merits.
